entries: The constricted creature takes 26 ({@damage 3d12 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}) and {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Ink Cloud {@recharge}
entries: The colossal squid emits black, poisonous ink in a 30-foot cloud as a bonus action while underwater. The cloud affects vision as the darkness spell, and any creature that starts its turn inside the cloud takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw. The colossal squid's {@sense darkvision} is not impaired by this cloud. The cloud persists for 1 minute, then disperses.

action.name: Vomit Forth the Deeps (1/Day)
entries: The colossal squid sprays half-digested food from its maw over a 15-foot cone. This acidic slurry causes 18 ({@damage 5d6}) acid damage and targets must make a successful {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the end of their next turn.

Colossal squids traverse the depths of the sea, usually unseen by the common sailor. With eight muscular arms and two long tentacles, these creatures could be mistaken for the offspring of a Great Olde One. On very rare occasions, these animals travel to the surface of the sea, often giving rise to tales of krakens in the area. In actuality, it’s in order to escape their natural predator, the sperm whale.

trait.name: Brutal Wings
entries: The valstrax deals one extra die of its damage when the valstrax hits with its wing attack (included in the attack).

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the valstrax fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The valstrax doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the valstrax is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the valstrax instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The valstrax makes five attacks: one with its bite, two with its talons, and two with its wing. Alternatively, it attacks four times with its plasmatic hurl.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 9}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d6 + 9}) slashing damage.

action.name: Wing
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 3d10 + 9}) slashing damage plus an additional 14 ({@damage 3d8}) force damage.

action.name: Plasmatic Hurl
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 14} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 9}) force damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) fire damage.

action.name: Ignition {@recharge 5}
entries: The valstrax primes its wings, sending a scorching blast of flame sweeping in every direction. Each creature within 15 feet of the valstrax must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 49 ({@damage 9d10}) force damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one. The valstrax can then fly up to 600 feet in any direction. Each creature with 10 feet of the valstrax during this movement must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or take 32 ({@damage 5d10}) thunder damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

bonus.name: Jet Propulsion
entries: While the valstrax is flying, it uses the dash action.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The valstrax attacks once with its plasmatic hurl or wing.

legendary.name: Blast Off
entries: The valstrax flies up to its speed.

legendary.name: Dragon Rush (2 Actions)
entries: The valstrax swirls and dances in the air, creating a ball of plasma centered on itself. The valstrax then flies up to its speed until it collides with something. Each object or creature within 30 feet of the valstrax when it collides must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength or Dexterity saving throw (target's choice) or be knocked {@condition prone} and take 46 ({@damage 7d10 + 8}) force damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage. On a successful save, the creature takes only half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.
{@i With a thunderous blast, a scaly, bird-like creature weaves through the sky with unmatched speed and skill. A trail of flaming red energy extends behind it.}

{@b Red Comet.} The valstrax is a bird-like reptile with large, wing-like appendages extending from its shoulder blades.  Quick and ruthless, the valstrax dominates the skies, darting and weaving around prey while slashing it to bits. A valstrax’s seemingly supernatural speed is the result of the creature’s specialized anatomy. On the ends of both of the beast’s “wings” are three openings that expel plasma produced via a special organ in its chest.  Known as the atriox, the organ rapidly sucks in air before releasing it through the wings as a form of exhaust. This method of propulsion allows the valstrax to soar at outrageous speeds, making it the fastest flying beast known to scholars. While flying at high speeds, the valstrax soars at such high altitudes that only its crimson exhaust can be seen. This trail of crimson fire has earned it the name “Red Comet.”

{@b Aerial Fighter.} The valstrax rarely fights on the ground. It strikes from above with speed and power, ripping prey to shreds in mere moments. The valstrax is capable of flipping its wings in two different directions: backwards, which allows it to fly at high speeds, and forwards; attacking foes from a distance by expelling plasma as a devastating projectile.

{@b Noble Predator.} While grounded, valstrax are normally quite docile, regularly tolerating the presence of other nonaggressive creatures. Valstrax have even been known to defend smaller and weaker creatures from larger threats. This protective and tolerant behavior has led to many crests and flags bearing the aspect of a valstrax.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The cryoceros has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Barreling Charge
entries: If the cryoceros moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an additional 14 {@damage 2d10} piercing damage. If the target is a creature that is Huge or smaller, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the cryoceros can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The cryoceros can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10+ 6}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} creature. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shards of Ice {@recharge 4}
entries: The cryoceros exhales razor-sharp ice in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 ({@damage 5d6}) cold damage and 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.
This enormous, squat beast has a shaggy hide of ice. Two translucent horns protrude from its snout, the frontmost of which looks like a scimitar.

entries.name: Elemental-Touched Rhino
entries: A cryoceros resembles a woolly rhinoceros made of ice. Its thick, frozen hide protects the soft flesh at its core, and a layer of ice forms over its already formidable, keratinous horns. The creature's body is efficient at transferring warmth to its fleshy interior; fire still harms a cryoceros, but its icy form is not unduly damaged by fiery attacks. A cryoceros has a second stomach that stores ice it consumes. As a defense mechanism, the cryoceros can spew stinging, pulverized ice from this alternate stomach.

entries.name: Slow Metabolisms
entries: Cryoceroses survive on stunted grasses and other plants that thrive in the tundra, as well as ice and snow, to replenish their icy exteriors. Despite their size, they don't require a great deal of sustenance, and they conserve their energy by slowly grazing across frozen plains. Their ponderous movement fools the unwary into believing that distance equals safety. Indeed, cryoceroses endure much provocation before they decide to act, but they run at and spear or crush those who irritate them. Once their ire is up, they rarely give up pursuing the source of their anger; only by leaving their vast territories can one hope to escape them.

entries.name: Cantankerous Mounts
entries: Gentleness and a regular source of food temporarily earns the cryoceroses' trust, and patient humanoids can manage to train the creatures to accept riders. This works for convenience much more than for combat, since cryoceroses balk at fighting with loads on their backs. A cryoceros in combat with a rider either stands stock still until its rider dismounts or, worse, rolls over to throw its rider, often crushing the rider in the process. Because of this, most tribes who train cryoceroses use the creatures as beasts of burden rather than war mounts.

trait.name: Awful Stench
entries: The vulture has a disgusting body odor. Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the vulture must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The vulture has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The vulture has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the vulture's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The death vulture makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Decaying Breath {@recharge 6}
entries: The vulture breathes necrotic energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) necrotic damage on a failed save and being afflicted with {@condition flesh rot}. On a successful saving throw, the target takes half as much damage and does not contract {@condition flesh rot}. Any afflicted creature must repeat the save at the end of each long rest, ending the effect on itself on a success.
The putrid stench of death wafts off a grotesquely muscled vulture with glowing green eyes. It opens its mouth in a shrill call, rotting meat dripping from its beak.
Death vultures are giant birds transformed by their diet of undead flesh.

entries.name: Mutant Abominations
entries: When a giant vulture gorges on undead flesh, the necromantic magic suffused in the meal warps and changes the bird's body. The vulture's muscles bulge in odd places, making it stronger and tougher, its eyes burn with green fire, and it reeks of rot, earning these mutated monsters the name "death vultures." The vulture also gains the ability to regurgitate necromantic energy, which can cause the flesh of living creatures to decay and rot rapidly.

entries.name: Massive Meat Appetites
entries: Death vultures have incredible appetites and are far more willing to attack live prey than other vultures. They have a special taste for rotting flesh, and they use their decaying breath weapon to "season" their foes with necrotic energy before using their talons and beaks to tear apart their quarry.

entries.name: Necromancer Neighbors
entries: Death vultures often form kettles near the lairs of necromancers as they feed on their undead creations. While some necromancers find the birds to be a nuisance, many necromancers feed the vultures, encouraging them to stay. Most death vultures are willing to trade their service as guardians for food.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the deinocheirus can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deinocheirus makes one attack with its claw and one with its tail.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 6d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Flurry {@recharge 5}
entries: The deinocheirus makes up to five claw attacks.

The deinocheirus is a massive ornithomimosaur that uses its impressive bulk and razor-sharp claws to survive. An omnivorous giant, the deinocheirus resembles a giant duck with theropod-like proportions and a long, boney sail running down the length of its spine. While normally docile, deinocheiruses are known to fight with terrifying ferocity when cornered.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The bear has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bear makes two attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws. If both claw attacks hit a Large or smaller creature, the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Expansive
entries: A creature at least one size smaller than the dreadnoughtus can travel through and finish its turn in the dreadnoughtus' space.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The dreadnoughtus deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dreadnoughtus makes one stomp attack and one tail attack.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}36 ({@damage 5d10 + 9}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the creature is knocked {@condition prone}, the dreadnoughtus immediately moves into the creature's space as a bonus action and crushes the creature beneath its bulk. The crushed creature can't breathe, is {@condition restrained}, and takes 32 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage at the start of each of the dreadnoughtus' turns. A crushed creature remains in its space and does not move with the dreadnoughtus. A crushed creature can escape by using an action and making a successful {@dc 19} Strength check. On a success, the creature crawls into an empty space within 5 feet of the dreadnoughtus.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}48 ({@damage 6d12 + 9}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be thrown up to 30 feet away and knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Earth-Shattering Slam {@recharge 5}
entries: The dreadnoughtus can rear up high into the clouds before slamming back down into the earth, sending a shock wave through the ground in a 120-foot-radius circle centered on itself. That area becomes difficult terrain for 1 minute. Each creature on the ground that is concentrating must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw or the creature's concentration is broken.

The shockwave deals 100 thunder damage to all structures in contact with the ground in the area. If a creature is near a structure that collapses, the creature might be buried; a creature within half the distance of the structure's height must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 17 ({@damage 5d6}) bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}, and is trapped in the rubble. A trapped creature is {@condition restrained}, requiring a successful {@dc 20} Strength (Athletics) check as an action to escape. Another creature within 5 feet of the buried creature can use its action to clear rubble and grant advantage on the check. If three creatures use their actions in this way, the check is an automatic success. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and doesn't fall {@condition prone} or become trapped.

This colossal sauropod remains the largest beast to roam the planet, flattening landscapes under its thunderous footsteps. Its long, muscular tail can be used to pulverize even the most durable creatures with tremendous force.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The eel hound can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The eel hound has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the hound's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Slick Spittle
entries: By spending 2 rounds dribbling spittle on an area, an eel hound can cover a 5-foot square with its slippery saliva. This area is treated as if under the effects of a {@spell grease} spell, but it lasts for 1 hour.

trait.name: Slithering Bite
entries: A creature an eel hound attacks can't make opportunity attacks against it until the start of the creature's next turn.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}).

{@i A grotesque beast with the muscular tail, bulbous head, and the rubbery, slime-covered flesh of a hideous eel, the torso and webbed paws of this amphibious predator resemble those of a misshapen canine. Needle-sharp teeth fill the creature's menacing jaws.}

entries.name: Hounds of the River Fey
entries: Ferocious aquatic fey, these amphibious menaces often serve such masters as lake and river trolls, lorelei, and nixies. Predatory beasts as dangerous on land as they are in the water, they share their masters' capricious cruelty. The hounds' chilling hunting cries inspire their masters to a killing frenzy as they pursue foes. Few other creatures appreciate eel hounds' lithe power and cruel grace, instead noting only their grotesque form and unnerving savagery.

entries.name: Slippery Ambushers
entries: Eel hounds are ambush predators, preferring to hide among the muck and algae of riverbanks, only to suddenly burst forth as a pack. They surround their prey, latching on with their powerful jaws. Non-aquatic prey are dragged into the depths to drown. Similarly, eel hounds often force aquatic prey up onto dry land to die of suffocation.

Possessed of a low cunning, they prepare ambushes by vomiting forth their slippery spittle where land animals come to drink or along game trails. They surge out of the water to snatch prey while it is off balance.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder balloon spider's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Adjust Density
entries: As a bonus action, the elder balloon spider can magically alter the weight of one object or creature that it can see within 30 feet of it if the object or creature is Huge or smaller, including itself. The target's weight is halved or doubled for up to 1 minute.

While the weight of a creature is halved by this effect, the creature's speed increases by 20 feet, it can jump three times as far as normal, it has disadvantage on Strength checks and saving throws and advantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws.

While the weight of a creature is doubled by this effect, the creature's speed is reduced by 20 feet, its jump distance is halved, its attacks deal an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage, it has advantage on Strength checks and saving throws and disadvantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws.

The elder balloon spider can have only one target's weight altered at a time. If the elder balloon spiders alters the density of another creature while already altering another, the first effect immediately ends.

trait.name: Erratic Discharge
entries: A creature or object that starts its turn within 10 feet of the elder balloon spider must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 2 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage. On a success, the creature takes no damage.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The elder balloon spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder balloon spider uses its reel in. It then makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Charged Web {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 40/80 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) by strands of charged webbing and begins to hover 10 feet off the ground. Until this grapple ends, the target takes 6 lightning damage at the start of each of its turns and is retrained. In addition, the {@condition grappled} target can make a {@dc 16} Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to manipulate the strands of webbing and fly 10 feet in any direction.

action.name: Reel In
entries: The elder balloon spider reels in all creatures {@condition grappled} by its webbing up to 15 feet toward it. If this movement pulls the creature within 5 feet of the balloon spider, the spider can make one bite attack against the creature as a free action.

action.name: Event Horizon {@recharge}
entries: The elder balloon spider expels a burst of powerful localized gravity in a 30 foot radius, originating from the balloon spider. Falling damage in the area increases to {@dice 1d10} per 10 feet fallen. When a creature starts its turn within the area or enters it for the first time in a turn, including when the spider creates the field, it must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure the creature is {@condition restrained}. On a success the creature's speed is halved as long as it remains in the field. A {@condition restrained} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn. The elder balloon spider is immune to the effects of its event horizon. The field persists until the spider's event horizon recharges again.

reaction.name: Gravitic Manipulation
entries: When a creature within 60 feet of the elder balloon spider, including itself, hits or is hit with a weapon attack, the balloon spider can use its reaction to increase or decrease the attack's velocity, causing the attack's target to take an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage or reduce the damage dealt by 7 ({@dice 2d6}).
Alternatively, if a creature within 60 feet of the spider takes damage from a fall, including itself, the spider can use its reaction to increase or reduce the fall's damage by 16 ({@dice 3d10}).

Balloon spiders are often captured or killed by those looking to collect their prized webbing, but those who manage to survive until maturity undergo a molting process that makes their chitinous flesh thicker and more conductive, allowing them to more effectively manipulate the electromagnetic fields that surround them. These elder balloon spiders grow to the size of horses and are capable of controlling electromagnetic forces and even gravity itself. Their nests often defy the natural forces of gravity and are considered cursed by some.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the wolf's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf makes two bite attacks. If both attacks hit the target and the target is a creature, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition frightened} it takes an additional 22 ({@damage 2d10}) cold damage. This attack ignores damage resistance.

action.name: Call the Pack (Recharges on a Long Rest)
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf magically duplicates itself, creating up to three spiritual replicas at a point it can see within 60 feet of itself that is not being occupied by another creature. Each replica uses the statistics of the Fang of the Great Wolf except it has 24 hit points and does not have access to Call the Pack, Howling Winds, or multiattack actions. The Great Wolf can communicate telepathically with a replica as long as they are on the same plane of existence. The Great Wolf can innately see, hear, and smell whatever any of its replicas sense. The replicas act as allies of the Great Wolf and obey its telepathic commands, taking their turns immediately after the Great Wolf. The replicas remain until killed or dismissed by the Great Wolf as a bonus action. Slain or dismissed replicas vaporize into glowing blue wisps of rime.

action.name: Howling Winds {@recharge 5}
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf emits a keening howl of freezing wind in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. In addition, each creature in that area that isn't {@condition deafened} must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of the Great Wolf until the end of the wolf's next turn. While a creature is {@condition frightened} in this way, its speed is halved, and it is {@condition incapacitated}.

variant.name: Maw of the Great Hyena
entries: While most individuals only view hyenas as the tainted offspring of Yeenoghu, they are still wild beasts, and aspects of nature still take hold of them on occasion. Roaming the savannas and deserts is a fierce hyena the size of a horse, cackling and snarling amidst the intense heat that radiates off of it. The Maw of the Great Hyena's abilities are almost identical to the Fang of the Great Wolf's, although their cold-oriented abilities and immunities are replaced with fire.
{@italic A lone wolf, white as snow, corners a bull moose. Suddenly, runes and sigils begin to glow on its fur, and the wolf splits into two, and then four, and finally six separate canines.}

In the frigid tundra of Faerûn, near the Icewind Dale, legends of a white wolf covered in glowing runes, sigils, and symbols spread through sailing crews and taverns like wildlfire. They say it hides within the tundra, with its pale, frosted fur allowing it to hide amongst the dark and snow. They also mention that one to seems to turn into two, and two into six. These claims are often dismissed, but most would be keen to listen to these survivors for their own safety.

{@bold Self-Made Pack.} Fangs of the Great Wolf are pure white dire wolves, save for several sigils and runes that line their fur. Upon first glance, the Fang looks to be a regular wolf, albeit with some physical differences. However, the abilities of the Fang of the Great Wolf only become evident when the wolf begins hunting. When stalking prey, the Fang’s runes begin to glow a ghostly blue, summoning a number of duplicates that seemingly manifest from nothing but wind and snow. The beast’s howl has a paralyzing effect, filling whatever hears it with terrible dread, forcing them into a panic. The Fangs instinctually give chase, bringing the prey to its knees and dragging it off into the storm to be devoured.

{@bold Godly Beasts.} Fangs of the Great Wolf are dire wolves that are specifically selected by divine creatures. It is said that seeing a Fang and surviving is considered the ultimate sign of good luck.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fire goose makes two attacks with its wing blades.

action.name: Wing Blades
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The fire goose breathes fire in a 20-foot cone. Every creature in the area must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. The goose's fire breath ignites flammable objects and melts soft metals in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

reaction.name: Honking Dissonance
entries: When the fire goose is hit with an attack, it can use its reaction to emit a horrendous cacophony of screams directly from the tortured souls of the lower planes. Creatures within 20 feet that can hear the goose must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} for 1 round. A creature {@condition incapacitated} in this way has its speed reduced to 0.
{@i This goose-like creature's feathers are razor sharp like shining metal. When it inhales, the feathers on its chest glow red hot.}

Fire geese are malevolent, deadly creatures originating from the Lower Planes. They grow feathers like their Material Plane counterparts, but their feathers are rigid and sharp like gleaming, edged metal.

{@b Ferrivorous Feathers.} The plumage of a fire goose displays a stunning mixture of metallic colors, which vary depending on their diet. The fire goose uses its fire breath to melt metals with low melting points such as gold, silver, lead, copper, and bronze, along with the orphanages. The fire goose consumes the molten metal, some of which migrates into the creature's deadly feathers. Fire geese that display primarily or entirely a single color are highly prized, but dangerous to capture.

{@b Malevolent Pseudo-Demons.} Like most geese, the fire goose is an irritable and aggressive creature, but unlike its mundane kin, the fire goose is blazingly malevolent, taking to the skies and melting towns and villages like a miniature dragon. Despite its small stature, it’s surprisingly dangerous and extremely confrontational.

trait.name: Ghostwalk
entries: As a bonus action, the ghostwalk spider becomes {@condition invisible} and intangible. Attacking doesn't end this invisibility. While {@condition invisible}, the ghostwalk spider has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks and gains the following:
{@b Damage Resistances.} acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical weapons
{@b Condition Immunities} {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition petrified}, {@condition prone}, {@condition restrained}, {@condition stunned}
The ghostwalk ends when the spider chooses to end it as a bonus action or when the spider dies.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement (During Ghostwalk Only)
entries: The ghostwalk spider can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ghostwalk spider makes two bite attacks. It can make a ghostly snare attack in place of one of its bites.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) poison damage, or half poison damage with a successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} and {@condition paralyzed} for 1 hour, even after regaining hit points. While using Ghostwalk, the spider's bite and poison do half damage to targets that aren't affected by Ghostly Snare (see below).

action.name: Ghostly Snare (During Ghostwalk Only, Recharge 5–6)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 40/160 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} by ghostly webbing. While {@condition restrained} in this way, the target is {@condition invisible} to all creatures except ghostwalk spiders, and it has resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, and thunder damage. A creature {@condition restrained} by Ghostly Snare can escape by using an action to make a successful {@dc 14} Strength check, or the webs can be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 5).
{@i A pasty-white spider the size of a horse slinks through the shadows. Its dull eyes fix on you as it fades from sight with a ghostly blue shimmer.}

Ghostwalk spiders are malevolent hunters that sprang from misguided experiments on phase spiders. They are spindly, emaciated things all but devoid of color. The spider is 8 feet in diameter (including legs) and weighs 500 pounds.

entries.name: Phantom Webs
entries: Ghostwalk spiders spin ephemeral webs in secluded areas. They spend most of their time stalking prey to paralyze and drag back to their phantom web. As long as these remains lie tangled in ghostly webs they go unnoticed by material creatures, but the spiders eventually cast old kills aside. Adventurers are wise to fear empty caves containing unexplained, desiccated remains.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the buffalo moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the buffalo can make one hooves attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Sturdy
entries: When the buffalo fails a Constitution saving throw that deals damage, it takes only half damage. On a success, it takes no damage.

trait.name: Trample
entries: When the buffalo takes the Dash action, it can move through the space of a Medium or smaller creature, treating the creature's space as difficult terrain. As it moves through the creature's space, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 23 ({@damage 3d10}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, it can't take reactions until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the target negates these effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The buffalo deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} creature. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The giant ribbon worm can breathe air and water.

action.name: Spit Up
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, 30 ft. cone., {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) acid damage, and any target hit by the giant ribbon worm's spit up is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}) and {@condition restrained}. Ability checks made to escape this grapple have disadvantage.

action.name: Digest
entries: The giant ribbon worm secretes digestive enzymes from its proboscis. Any creature {@condition grappled} by the giant ribbon worm must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 6 ({@damage 2d4}) acid damage and 6 ({@damage 2d4}) necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

bonus.name: Reel
entries: The giant ribbon worm reels its proboscis back into its body. Any creature {@condition grappled} by the giant ribbon worm's proboscis when it is retracted must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage and falling {@condition prone} on a failed save and escaping the grapple unharmed on a successful one. Whether on a failure or a success, the target is no longer {@condition grappled}.

{@i This slimy, segmented worm slithers between land and sea, vomiting up a long, branching proboscis onto any unfortunate creatures it may come across. It doesn’t take long for captured prey to be dissolved and digested.}

{@b Acidic Stomach.} The giant ribbon worm is a human-sized nemertean with an unquenchable hunger. The giant ribbon worm has a proboscis that is attached to its pale, spongey stomach. To capture and digest prey, the worm will spit its proboscis up onto any potential meal. The proboscis branches out, covering a wide area with prehensile tendrils that grasp and restrain anything that resists. From there, digestive enzymes are directly injected into the victim, reducing them to a slurry of digestible juices known as chyme. The chyme is absorbed into the proboscis and quickly retracted back into the giant ribbon worm’s body.

trait.name: Cryptobiosis
entries: When exposed to an environment or effect that is lethal to the tardigrade over time, such as an environment that lacks breathable water, being frozen solid, or taking poison damage over time, the tardigrade enters a state of suspended animation. While in this state, the tardigrade is {@condition unconscious} but immune to any environmental effects, as well as poison and necrotic damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition. Any such ongoing effect is suspended but not removed. The cryptobiotic state ends as soon as conditions become tolerable for the tardigrade. The tardigrade can remain in this state for up to 30 years. If it remains in this state longer, it dies.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The tardigrade can breathe air and water.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4 ‒1}) piercing damage.

Similar to their microscopic counterparts, giant tardigrades are extremely resilient. Capable of surviving the most desolate and harsh environments, giant tardigrades would be considered extremely dangerous if it weren’t for their complete lack of strength and power.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gigantopithecus makes one bite attack and two fist attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, the gigantopithecus can choose to grapple it (escape {@dc 16}).

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 40/80 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Throw
entries: One Medium or smaller object or creature {@condition grappled} by the gigantopithecus  is thrown up to 15 feet in a random direction and knocked {@condition prone}. If a thrown target strikes a solid surface, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 5 feet it was thrown. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Charging Bluff
entries: The gigantopithecus moves at least 15 feet in a straight line and then roars and beats its chest. Each creature of the gigantopithecus' choice within 20 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of the gigantopithecus until the end of its next turn.

bonus.name: Pummel {@recharge 5}
entries: The gigantopithecus makes four fist attacks against a {@condition prone} target within 5 feet of it.

Reigning over all other apes, the gigantopithecus is an animal of immense strength and power. Falling just short of giant apes in terms of sheer power, the gigantopithecus is a noble defender of the jungle, pummeling anything that may seek to destroy it. Thanks to their normally docile nature, gigantopithecus play a valuable role as companions to forest druids and rangers.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The stag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the golden stag moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

{@italic As Helvetica lie, helpless and dying, her companions could do nothing more than comfort her in her final moments. As her breathing became shallow, her friends knew she was nearing her last. Before she had the chance to take in her final breath, an elk cloaked in a golden sheen stepped out of the thick fog, approaching the group like a noble ruler. Wordlessly, the party allowed the animal to approach Helvetica, where it gently enveloped her with its crown of golden antlers. A dim, radiant light poured from the beast’s royal circlet of bone, and within moments, Helvetica stretched her limbs casually as if awoken from a deep slumber.}

Golden stags are magical cousins to elk and other cervids. It is an avid protector of the animals in its forest, often coming to their rescue. A golden stag is also sympathetic to those who get lost in its woods or seem to struggle with survival in the cold. The creature beckons unfortunate travelers to follow it to safety, often just outside a village it knows to be friendly. If a visitor to a forest overseen by a golden stag has a peaceful encounter with the creature, the stag might later come to that visitor's aid, protecting it from predatory animals or rescuing it from some natural hazard. Additionally, the golden stag commands some innate healing ability, using it to heal the sick, wounded, or dying. Many desperate travelers bring loved ones to forests inhabited by golden stags in hope of receiving help from the forest guardian.

trait.name: Expansive
entries: A creature at least one size smaller than the goliath longlegs can travel through and finish its turn in the goliath longlegs' space.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While a goliath longlegs remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from other plants or trees.

trait.name: Forest Camouflage
entries: The goliath longlegs has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in forested terrain.

trait.name: Vulnerable Legs
entries: The goliath longlegs has eight legs. While it has more than four legs, the goliath longlegs is immune to being knocked {@condition prone} or {@condition restrained}. Whenever the goliath longlegs takes 20 or more damage in a single turn, one of its legs is destroyed. Each time a leg is destroyed after the fourth one, the goliath longlegs must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or fall {@condition prone}. Any creature in the goliath longlegs' space or within 5 feet of it when it falls {@condition prone} must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The goliath longlegs makes one bite attack and then as many leg attacks as it has legs. It can use its Reel in place of two leg attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, even after regaining hit points, and is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} in this way.

action.name: Leg
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 1d12 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Paralytic Web {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one Large or smaller creature. {@h}The creature is {@condition restrained} by webbing and must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition paralyzed} effect on itself on a success. As an action, the {@condition restrained} creature can make a {@dc 18} Strength check, escaping from the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 14; hp 30; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

action.name: Reel
entries: The goliath longlegs pulls one creature caught in its web up to 30 feet straight toward it. If the target is within 10 feet of the goliath longlegs, the goliath longlegs can make one bite attack as a bonus action.
{@i A spider the size of a large house, with legs that could pass for trees, moves through the forest.}
Solitary hunters, goliath longlegs sit motionless for long periods of time, waiting for unsuspecting prey to walk beneath them.

entries.name: Stealthy Ambush Predators
entries: The legs of a goliath longlegs mimic the size and texture of the trees of the forest in which it resides. It uses this natural camouflage to its advantage, hiding its body in the crowns of the nearby trees.

entries.name: Venomous Weapons
entries: The goliath longlegs' legs are vulnerable to attack, so it prefers to poison its prey with a paralyzing nerve agent.

entries.name: Unknown Origin
entries: Not much is known about the origin of this species. They are few in number, and, when one is discovered, word rarely gets back to civilization.

trait.name: Aura of Death
entries: Provided the gray quoxxarie isn’t {@condition incapacitated}, any creature hostile to the quoxxarie that starts its turn within 30 feet of one or more gray quoxxaries has disadvantage on death saving throws. Halve the hit points creatures regain if they are hostile to the quoxxarie and in one or more quoxxarie Aura of Death.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the gray quoxxarie moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its ram on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d10}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The gray quoxxarie has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The gray quoxxarie's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gray quoxxarie makes one ram attack and one hooves attack.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21({@damage 2d12 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Get the Horns
entries: If the gray quoxxarie takes damage from one creature within 40 feet of it, the quoxxarie can take the Disengage action and move up to half its speed toward that creature. If the creature is then within reach, the quoxxarie can make a ram attack against it with advantage on the attack roll.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: While out of water, the great octopus can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage
entries: The great octopus has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The great octopus can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The great octopus deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The great octopus makes four attacks with its tentacles.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 40 ft., one creature. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}). Until this grapple ends, the creature is {@condition restrained}, and the tentacle can't constrict another target. The great octopus has eight tentacles, each of which can grapple only one target.

Every sailor knows the stories of krakens and large, tentacled beasts that drag ships into the frigid deep. Not many of them know that these stories usually stem from sightings of the giant octopus, a powerful cephalopod of titanic proportions. With nothing left to satisfy its tremendous appetite, giant octopuses have been observed preying on humpback whales, holding them underwater until they drown. Extremely long-lived, there are individuals thought to be over thousands of years old.

trait.name: Desert Camouflage
entries: The great scorpion has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in desert terrain.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: The great scorpion has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The great scorpion makes two attacks: two with its claws and one with its stinger.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). The scorpion has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) piercing damage. The target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 6d10}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the hell pig moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a bite attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The hell pig has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) and {@condition restrained}.

Also known as enteledonts, hell pigs are hulking, muscular predators that are closely related to the wild boar. Hell pigs hunt in pairs, using their impressive bulk to tackle prey before ripping into them with their powerful jaws. Despite being omnivorous, hell pigs usually live a carnivorous lifestyle.

trait.name: Massive Frame
entries: The tortoise can carry up to 600,000,000 pounds of weight atop its shell, but moves at half speed if the weight exceeds 300,000,000 pounds. Medium or smaller creatures can move underneath the tortoise while it's not {@condition prone}.
Any creature under the tortoise when it falls {@condition prone} is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). Until the grapple ends, the creature is {@condition prone} and {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 2d8 + 9}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shell Defense {@recharge 4}
entries: The tortoise withdraws into its shell, falls {@condition prone}, and gains a +5 bonus to AC. While the tortoise is in its shell, its speed is 0 and can't increase. The tortoise can emerge from its shell as an action, whereupon it is no longer {@condition prone}.

Desolate badlands and soggy marshes are home to the ancient and massive horizonback tortoises. Nearly fifty feet from nose to tail, and with a habit of remaining stationary for long periods, a horizonback tortoise is easy to mistake for a low hill at a distance. But when these impressive creatures rise to begin their march, the sight inspires fear and awe in equal parts. An omnivore of incredible size, these scavengers prefer to feed on dead vegetation, but make use of whatever edible matter they come across.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The huecambra makes three attacks: one with its bite, one with its claw, and one with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or become cursed. While cursed, the creature grows gem-like growths across its body. When the cursed creature takes damage that isn't poison or psychic, it and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This damage doesn't trigger further explosions. The curse lasts until it is lifted by a {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Gem Explosion {@recharge 6}
entries: The huecambra causes some of the gem-like nodules on its body to detonate. Each creature within 20 feet of the huecambra must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 24 ({@damage 7d6}) thunder damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition stunned}. A creature cursed by the huecambra's bite has disadvantage on this saving throw.

The squat lizard's body is dappled gray and chocolate-brown and covered in colorful, wart-like gems, most prominently over its back and along its thick tail. It has long claws, a mouth full of needle-like fangs, and a gleam of intelligence in its multifaceted amber eyes.

entries.name: Mysterious Jungle Hunters
entries: The huecambra is an unusual and rarely seen predator native to tropical jungles and swamps. It hides amid tall reeds or in murky stretches of water, covering itself in mud to hide the gleam of the gem-like growths covering its body. Basilisks, crocodiles, and venomous snakes are the favored prey of a huecambra, though it eats just about anything it can catch. While the true origin of the huecambra remains a mystery, the people of the jungles and swamps where the monster lives believe the creature to be born from the soul of a person overcome with greed and vanity.

entries.name: Gems with Teeth
entries: The huecambra is often hunted for its gem-like growths, which are useful in constructing magic items that protect their wearers from petrification and poison. The luster of the gems also inspires humanoids to hunt them, and brooches and necklaces of huecambra gems are popular items among the social elite of certain countries and city-states.

trait.name: Draconic Predator
entries: The ichneumon is immune to a dragon's Frightful Presence and has advantage on saving throws against the breath weapons of dragons.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the ichneumon is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the ichneumon instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The ichneumon has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Mud Armor
entries: If the ichneumon spends an hour applying mud to itself, it can increase its AC by 2 for 8 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ichneumon makes three attacks. two with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the ichneumon can't use its bite on another target.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage.
{@i With powerful jaws and teeth capable of shearing scales from meat with ease, the creature resembles a weasel the size of a brown bear.}

entries.name: Outsized Temerity
entries: These creatures live in burrows and caves whose previous inhabitants were likely devoured by the new residents. Wily hunters, ichneumons prey upon all kinds of creatures, but they go to great lengths and far out of their way to feast on dragon eggs, or the dragons themselves if they can.

entries.name: Resourceful Rodent
entries: Ichneumons have a keen animal intelligence, and they make an innovative use of their environment. A musky oil with insulating properties coats the fur of an ichneumon, granting it a measure of protection. When an ichneumon has the luxury of time to prepare before hunting, it finds the nearest source of mud and applies layer after layer to itself. The mud bonds with the creature's oily coat and forms a hard, thick outer armor, enhancing its natural protections.

entries.name: Hunted and Hated
entries: The ichneumon's very existence is a source of humiliation and outrage for dragonkind. The mention of a dragon's name who was killed by an ichneumon is considered distasteful among dragons once they have hunted for the killer and settled the matter. Different standards of decency apply for other beings, however, and any non-dragon foolish enough to mention an ichneumon within hearing of a dragon might never be heard from again.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The ithjar has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Slippery Serpent
entries: The ithjar has advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to escape a grapple or saving throws to avoid being {@condition paralyzed} or {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ithjar attacks once with its bite and once with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Constrict
entries: {@i Melee Weapon Attack:} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Large or smaller creature. {@i Hit:} 17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) slashing damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}) if the ithjar isn't already constricting a creature, and the target is {@condition restrained} until this grapple ends. If it has a target {@condition grappled}, the ithjar can't use its constrict against another creature

reaction.name: Writhing Escape
entries: When {@condition grappled}, the ithjar can attempt to escape.
{@i “It takes mere moments for an ithjar to transform from a kite-like swirl of gray and red in the distance to a menace of snapping teeth.”}

{@b Airborne Ophidian.} An ithjar is a monstrous, snake-like flying predator. It writhes through the clouds seeking prey with vision that rivals that of a raptor. Once an ithjar locates a potential meal, the ithjar flies in a strange, swirling fashion, reminiscent of a long-tailed kite. As the ithjar closes in, that curious flying pattern becomes a whirlwind of violence and death. Rows of slashing teeth line the crocodilian mouth of an ithjar. These fangs flay flesh from bone and can penetrate strong armor.

{@b Writhing Foe.} Opposite the ithjar’s mouth is a tail studded with spiked fins. The ithjar uses this tail to lash or ensnare prey. An ithjar’s lithe form and chaotic movement allows it to evade and confuse foes. But that’s not the only danger. The monster is hard to catch, escaping from a hold almost as quickly as a foe can wrestle it. An ithjar can quickly turn the tables on an enemy intent on capturing it. Its constricting coils can be as deadly as its bite.

{@b Stormborne Scourge.} Ithjars have been seen hunting alone, in small groups, and in packs. Such packs have been described as a glistening hurricane of scales, teeth, and blood. But far worse than the common ithjar is the stormborne ithjar. Those monsters add to their ferocity with the elemental powers of a storm.

trait.name: Nauseous Gas
entries: The kezai produces a faint, nauseating gas. Any creature that starts its turn within 20 feet of the kezai must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage. The area within 20 feet of the kezai is lightly obscured by the thin gas.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kezai makes three attacks: one with its poison barb and two with its claws.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Poison Barb
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and is {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. On a success, the creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the creature takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage at the start of each of its turns.

action.name: Searing Acid {@recharge 6}
entries: The kezai's mandibles drip a searing acid, instantly igniting the gas around it. Each creature within 20 feet of the kezai must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The kezai's Nauseous Gas trait becomes inactive for 1 minute. The kezai can't use Searing Gas unless Nauseous Gas has been active for at least 1 minute.
This creature looks much like a human-sized scorpion with wide, laced wings. The tip of its curled tail holds numerous barbs that drip sticky poison.

entries.name: Chemical Killing Machine
entries: The kezai is a creature that lives in hot climates and wages a chemical war on anything that opposes it. It emits a foul poison from its tail, coating the barbs that it hurls at enemies. If this wasn't deadly enough, it naturally produces a thin, flammable gas that it can ignite with a searing chemical produced in a gland near its mandibles. Fortunately for those who come across the kezai, the gland is slow-acting and takes time to produce the chemical necessary to ignite the gas.

trait.name: Bladed Tendrils
entries: The khanivore has four large tendrils extending from the back of its head which, on each of its turns as a bonus action, the khanivore can interlock to form one large tendril. It can separate them back into four tendrils again as a bonus action.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the khanivore is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the khanivore instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Tendril Climb (Separated Tendrils Only)
entries: The khanivore can use its tendrils to climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check. While the khanivore climbs this way, its arms and legs remain free, and at any point during this movement, it can choose to suspend itself any distance up to 10 feet away from the surface it is climbing.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The khanivore's long jump is up to 40 feet and its high jump is up to 20 feet, with or without a running start.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The khanivore has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the khanivore can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Primal Savagery
entries: The khanivore's attacks are feral and devastating. The khanivore's weapon attacks are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming damage resistance and immunity.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The khanivore makes three attacks: One with its bite and two with its claws. If the khanivore's tendrils are interlocked, it can also make an attack with its monotendril or its fling. If the khanivore's tendrils are separated and it is not climbing, it can instead make four tendril attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 4d4 + 6}) slashing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or lose 5 ({@damage 1d6}) hit points at the start of each of its turns due to a bloody wound. Each time the khanivore hits the wounded target with this attack, the damage dealt by the wound increases by 5 ({@damage 1d6}). Any creature can take an action to stanch the wound with a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom (Medicine) check. The wound also closes if the target receives magical healing.

action.name: Tendril (Separated Tendrils Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}) and {@condition restrained}. While it has a creature {@condition grappled}, the Khanivore can't attack with the grappling tendril. The khanivore has four tendrils, each of which can grapple only one target. A creature {@condition grappled} by the Khanivore can't breathe and takes 12 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage at the start of each of its turns.

action.name: Monotendril (Interlocked Tendrils Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) piercing damage. This attack scores a critical hit on a roll of 18–20.

On a critical hit, the target is impaled. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}) and {@condition restrained} until the grapple ends, at which point the creature is forced to make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw. A creature loses 13 ({@damage 2d12}) hit points due to blood loss on a failed save, or half as many hit points on a successful one.. The khanivore can't attack with its tendrils or separate them while it has a target impaled.

action.name: Fling (Interlocked Tendrils Only)
entries: With a flick of its tendril, the khanivore flings a Large or smaller target it has impaled, ending the effect. The khanivore makes a Strength (Athletics) check, and the target is flung in a straight line a distance in feet equal to 2 multiplied by the result of the khanivore's check (rounded up). The flung target travels the distance it was flung, or until it collides with a solid object or surface, taking 12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, plus an additional 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet of the fling distance.

If the flung target would collide with a creature, the creature in its path can make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw to avoid being struck. On a failed save, the flung target stops moving, and the struck creature and the flung target each take half of the bludgeoning damage that would be dealt by the fling. A creature in the path of the flung target can choose to fail this save if it wishes.

reaction.name: Duck and Weave (Separated Tendrils Only)
entries: The khanivore gains +5 to its AC against one attack that would hit it. To do so, the khanivore must see the source of the attack.

{@i A large predator resembling a mix between a cat, a lizard, and a gorilla stalks a group of humanoids from the forest’s canopy. Trailing behind it is a long, muscular tail with a serrated blade extending from the tip.}

{@b Odd Origins.} The khanivore is an odd creature, as it does not occur naturally. Unlike monstrosities that were created by arcane means, the khanivore was instead forged by a circle of powerful archdruids who sought a beast as indomitable as they were. The result was the khanivore, a predator of such strength, speed, and cunning that the druids were unable to contain it. Free and dangerous, the khanivore stalked and preyed on the continent, outliving even the druids that created it.

{@b Apex.} The khanivore was created with the purpose of being the most dangerous predator in the world. As a result, its predatory instincts render it aggressive, intelligent, and brutal. The khanivore quickly dominates any ecosystem it may find itself in, relentlessly hunting everything moving to near extinction. When it grows restless and bored, the khanivore migrates to a new territory, where it begins the cycle of death anew.

{@b Cunning Predator.} The khanivore is a master of utilizing each of its physical attributes to their fullest potential. It’s cat-like talons are retractable and can be used to create grievous slashes and wounds. Its dangerously powerful bite and muscular torso allow for it to lunge forward with explosive power, knocking potential prey off-guard. What initially resembles a prehensile tail can quickly split into four bladed tendrils, each of which are powerful enough to support the full body weight of the khanivore and squeeze the life out of anything unfortunate enough to be trapped in its coils. With such strength and agility, the various natural weapons of the khanivore make it the most dangerous and persistent predator in the natural world.
{@b Timeless.} The khanivore does not age, and effects that would age the khanivore immediately fail.

trait.name: Corrosive Mold
entries: A creature that starts its turn {@condition grappled} by the kirikari must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

trait.name: Misty Veil
entries: The kirikari emits a light fog within 30 feet of itself. The mist moves with the kirikari, lightly obscuring the area around it. If dispersed by a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour), the mist reappears at the start of the kirikari's next turn.

trait.name: Unseen Attacker
entries: On each of its turns, the kirikari can use a bonus action to take the {@action Hide} action. If the kirikari is hidden from a creature and hits it with an attack, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kirikari makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d12 + 5}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the kirikari can't bite another target.

action.name: Blinding Veil {@recharge 5}
entries: The kirikari expels a cloud of intensified mist, heavily obscuring everything within 30 feet of it. The mist thins back to lightly obscuring the area at the end of the kirikari's next turn.
Blanketed in a veil of mist, an enormous, centipede-like creature sifts its way through the swamp, the severed tail of a wyvern gripped tightly within its jaws.

Whenever an unnatural mist suddenly arises, some believe it to be the sign of a kirikari. Though they're rare and solitary creatures, kirikari are considered highly dangerous due to their heightened aggression and territorial behavior.

entries.name: Ambush Predators
entries: Few can spot a kirikari in hiding, as it appears as little more than a collapsed tree concealed in fog. It then waits patiently for its prey to draw near—before striking out at them with its lightning-fast bite.

entries.name: Symbiotic Relationship
entries: The mist that covers a kirikari's body comes from a unique type of mold that adheres to its carapace. The mold secretes an acid that evaporates harmlessly shortly after being exposed to air. The kirikari uses this mist to conceal itself and disorient its prey. Despite being natural-born swimmers, kirikari tend to avoid swimming in ocean waters, as exposure to salt quickly kills its mold.

entries.name: Wyvern Hunters
entries: Though unusual for its behavior, kirikari have been known to travel incredible distances to hunt down {@creature wyvern|mm|wyverns}. Some scholars theorize that the toxins within a wyvern's body are a necessary component in the maintenance of a kirikari's mold.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The kirin's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, +10 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The kirin is an 18th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, +10 to hit with spell attacks). The kirin has the following spells prepared:

trait.name: Command Lightning
entries: At the end of each of its turns, the kirin can choose three locations within 120 feet of it to be affected by the {@spell call lightning} spell. The lightning strikes at the beginning of its next turn.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the kirin fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The kirin has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The kirin's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kirin makes two attacks; one with its hooves and one with its horn.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Horn
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The kirin makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Smite
entries: The kirin makes an attack with its hooves or casts thunderclap.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The kirin moves up to its speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

{@italic The mythic Kirin resembles a unicorn, though closer inspection reveals that it is covered in rigid scales rather than a coat. Its majestic white mane and hair stand on end, as if charged with static. The equine beast often crackles with stray electricity.}

Kirin have radiant white fur used for collecting and effectively harnessing electricity. When a sufficient number of electrical currents have been accumulated, the Kirin will glow brightly, discharging vast amounts of electricity from its conductive hide, which will deflect almost all attacks. A Kirin's most vital feature, though, is its long, jagged horn. This horn is used to summon lightning from the sky, even when there isn't a storm cloud in sight. However, even if this horn is destroyed, Kirin are still capable of summoning lightning bolts with little effort.

Some of the more elusive, ancient, or plainly more potent individuals are known for having unusually strong electrical powers that are yet to be fully understood. Some of the larger, more powerful muscles are located in its legs, capable of delivering deadly kicks. Equipped with such powerful legs, all Kirin possess the ability to run at speeds so unexpectedly fast they appear to teleport, leaving behind a trail of blue, crackling electricity.

Kirin are as highly unpredictable as the lightning they harness. At times Kirin are tranquil, peaceful creatures, willing to share their chosen territory with large predators, while at others they are highly aggressive and territorial, trampling even mice if they so much as disturb the animal. In a distant legend, it was said that a Kirin destroyed an entire village simply because it made far too much noise for the irritable beast.

monster.name: Komodo Dragon
languages: understands Draconic but can't speak it

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The komodo dragon has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the komodo dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The komodo dragon attacks twice, once with its bite and once with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 13 ({@damage 3d8}) poison damage on a failed save and being {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the target failed its save, the creature must repeat the save every minute, taking 13 ({@damage 3d8}) poison damage on a failed save and half damage on a successful one. If the target succeeds on this save three consecutive times, the effect ends.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

variant.name: Draconic Aspect
entries: The komodo dragon can have any number of the following traits:

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: The komodo dragon can breathe air and water, and it has a swimming speed equal to its walking speed.

entries.name: Winged
entries: The komodo dragon has a flying speed of 60 feet..

entries.name: Venom Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) poison damage.

Komodo dragons are large lizards with long tails, strong and agile necks, and sturdy limbs. With a powerful bite and serrated teeth, the bite of a komodo dragon is dangerous. Deadlier still, a deadly neurotoxin and bacteria produced within the komodo dragon’s saliva ensures that anything that escapes the komodo’s bite won’t live long afterwards. The majesty and deadly might of the dragons became this reptile’s namesake for a reason.

{@b Draconic Reputation.} Komodo dragons haven’t always had such draconic characteristics. Long ago, komodo dragons were admittedly mundane beasts that wandered the forests and plains, named after dragons for their reptilian majesty. Over the years, it seems, various mad mages and transmutation wizards have experimented and altered on the lizards, causing them to become more draconic over time. These individuals were released into the wild, out-competing and out-breeding their mundane counterparts. Eventually, only the true dragons remained.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
