entries: The kravgaera has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The kravgaera can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Tunneler
entries: The kravgaera can burrow through solid rock at half its burrow speed and leaves a 10-foot-diameter tunnel in its wake.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The kravgaera doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kravgaera attacks once with its bite and twice with its claws. Alternatively, it makes two sonic lance attacks or two explosion attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the kravgaera can't bite another target or use any attack that deals thunder damage. When the kravgaera moves, any target it is grappling moves with it.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Sonic Lance
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +11} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 5d8}) thunder damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition deafened} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Explosion
entries: The kravgaera fires its sonic lance at a point on the ground, a large rock, stone wall, or similar terrain within 60 feet, causing the terrain to explode. Creatures within a 15-foot-radius sphere around the target point must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing and thunder damage on a failed save and be knocked {@condition prone} or half as much damage and remain standing on a successful one.

action.name: Deafening Screech {@recharge 5}
entries: The kravgaera roars loudly in a 30-foot-radius around it. Structures and unattended objects in the area take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) thunder damage. All creatures in the area become {@condition deafened} until the end of their next turn and must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw, taking 49 ({@damage 7d10}) thunder damage and becoming {@condition stunned} on a failed saving throw or half as much damage and not being {@condition stunned} on a successful one.
In addition, if a creature fails its save and is temporarily {@condition deafened}, they become permanently deaf.

{@italic This feathered, colorful pterosaur is covered by several rows of serrated spikes and jagged scales. The air near its toothed beak, large enough to carry a horse, visibly vibrates with sound pulses.}
High in the skies of Chult, kravgaera scream other airborne creatures out of the sky, grabbing them nimbly out of the air before plunging deep into the earth to consume their prey.

{@bold Scourge of the Skies.} Above the prehistoric jungles of chult, the kravgaera thrive and dominate, controlling the skies with a tyrannical scream. The ear-piercing shriek of these apex predators is enough to clear out entire populations of birds and pterosaurs, allowing them to scatter prey easily and claim territory with little to no competition. These bold predators will even battle large terrestrial animals for territory and are even known to prey on the occasional elephant or hadrosaur. These predators are covered in a thick, serrated carapace that allows them to burrow by writhing and “swimming” through the earth. They utilize their burrowing ability by transitioning to earth and sky rapidly, disorienting prey. These emperors of the sky even manage to hold their own against dragons, although they can’t survive a prolonged battle. As a result, these normally solitary and territorial creatures may band together to bully the magical reptiles out of the sky, thus condemning most dragons to the ground.

{@bold Blind Fliers.} Most sentient creatures think bats to be completely blind, navigating through keen senses and subsonic vibrations. Whilst this is simply misinformation, the kravgaera are truly blind, locating prey through echolocation and navigating via an internal GPS system, which is yet to be truly understood. It is theorized that, due to the creature’s vulnerability to electromagnesis, the kravgaera have an innate organ covered in specialized photoreceptors that allows the reptile to sense the planet’s Geomagnetism, similar to birds. However, this has yet to be proven, as the jungles of Chult rarely preserve the bodies of the dead, which are either scavenged or reanimated. Watching the rotting corpse of a zombified kravgaera soar through the tropical sky is an eerie sight, and it’s of the watcher’s best interest to hide before they are spotted.

{@bold Sonic Screams.} The screams of a kravgaera can be summarized by two words; loud and dangerous. These ear-splitting pterosaurs are capable of shrieking loud enough to emit powerful bursts of sound, acting as a concentrated explosion when colliding with a physical surface. These concentrated blasts are devastating to both organic and inorganic material, capable of causing severe physical damage and even destroying terrain. While deadly to potential prey and would-be predators, these sonic bursts are most devastating to other kravgaera, overloading their senses and causing them to plummet to the ground. It isn’t uncommon to find rival males nimbly evading each other, firing powerful shockwaves at one another before one is sent cascading to the jungle floor below, leaving only one to be the true emperor of the skies.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The lambeosaurus has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

trait.name: Perfect Mimicry
entries: The lambeosaurus can perfectly recreate any sound it has heard in the last 30 days, together with any effect a sound had. The sound is completely identical, and can't be discerned as a mimicry. If a certain sound has a magical effect, the lambeosaurus can recreate the spell and its effect as long as the spell had no material components, using the slot level, attack bonus, and spell save DC of the original caster.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Sonic Copy (3/Day)
entries: The lambeosaurus uses its perfect mimicry to recreate a sound and its effect (like the Wail of a banshee, the Luring Song of a harpy, one of the many sound of a parasaurolophus, or the Misty Step or Healing Word spell).

The lambeosaurus is a huge duck-billed hadrosaur with a distinctive hatchet-shaped bone crest atop its head. An adult lambeosaurus is generally 30 feet long and 13 feet tall when standing on all fours. Lambeosauruses are capable of walking on their hind legs, reaching up to over 22 feet tall. Lambeousauruses share the thumb-like fifth finger of most hadrosaurs, using it to grasp and hold objects. Social herbivores, the lambeosaurus commonly live in mixed groups of 4-7 adults and their offspring.

{@b Perfect Mimicry.} The hollow crest of a lambeosaurus is usually used to communicate with low murmurs and bird-like squeaks. However, this crest gives the lambeosaurus a unique ability to perfectly replicate any noise it has heard before. From the screech of a banshee to the verbal components of a powerful spell, lambeosaurs can be mistaken for powerful entities for their mimicking prowess.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The leedsichthys has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hp.

trait.name: Blood Scent
entries: The leedsichthys can smell blood in the water within 5 miles of it. It can determine whether the blood is fresh or old and what type of creature shed the blood. In addition, the leedsichthys has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to find or track a creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The leedsichthys deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The leedsichthys can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The leedsichthys makes one bite attack and one tail attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 6d6 + 8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Churn Water {@recharge 4}
entries: The leedsichthys thrashes violently. Each creature within 20 feet of the leedsichthys must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The water within 60 feet of the leedsichthys becomes difficult terrain for 1 minute. Each creature that starts its turn on the deck of a ship in this area must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or fall overboard.

trait.name: Acid Burn
entries: If a creature wearing armor or wielding a weapon takes acid damage from one of the loxorosa's attacks, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the loxorosa decides which one of the following effects happen:

{@bold Armor.} The armor it is wearing takes a cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Nonmagical armor reduced to an AC of 10 is destroyed. Magical armor reduced to an AC of 10 no longer gains the benefits of any of its magical properties for one week, but its AC returns to normal after a long rest.

{@bold Weapon.} The weapon takes a cumulative -1 penalty to its attack and damage rolls. A nonmagical weapon reduced to -5 in its attack and damage rolls is destroyed. A magical weapon reduced to -5 no longer gains the benefits of any of its properties for one week, but it becomes a mundane weapon after a long rest.
{@bold Corrosion} The target takes 10 ({@damage 4d4}) acid damage at the beginning of its next turn.

trait.name: Adapting Tusks
entries: The loxorosa can use its bonus action to to sharpen its tusks, removing the acidic moss that covers them; or it can use a bonus action to regrow it.

trait.name: Swamp Camouflage
entries: The loxorosa has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in swampy terrain.

trait.name: Trunk
entries: The loxorosa has a long, muscular trunk that can grasp objects and be used as a snorkel. It has a reach of 15 feet, and it can lift up to 700 pounds. When the loxorosa grapples a creature, it has a reach of 15 feet.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The loxorosa makes two tusk attacks. If both attacks hit the same target, the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength or Dexterity saving throw (target's choice) or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the loxorosa can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage when covered in acidic moss. If sharpened, the target takes 39 ({@damage 6d8 + 6}) piercing damage instead.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Goring Rush
entries: The loxorosa uses one of the following goring rush attacks depending on which form its tusks are in. Both share the same recharge.

{@bold Acidic Rush (Recharge 5–6).} The loxorosa launches itself forward 80 feet without provoking opportunity attacks, using its tusks to gore all foes within a 10-foot radius of its path. Each creature in that area must then make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 24 ({@dice 7d6}) slashing and 24 ({@damage 7d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

{@bold Sharpened Rush (Recharge 5–6).} The loxorosa launches itself forward 80 feet without provoking opportunity attacks, using its tusks to gore all foes within a 10-foot radius of its path. Each creature in that area must then make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 63 ({@damage 18d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

{@italic Wading through the murky, ink-like water, a massive mammoth lumbers through a dense swamp. Crocodiles surface in order to give it a wide berth, careful not to be crushed underneath this colossal beast. Acidic moss, fungi, and other various plant matter is intertwined with its fur, making it appear green and plant-like.}
The loxorosa is a massive swamp-dwelling proboscid that has formed a symbiotic relationship with the various forms of plant life that grows in its fur.

{@bold Lumbering Giants.} Like elephants and mammoths, the loxorosa is a lumbering titan that is capable of breaking into a thunderous charge, but it prefers to move slowly and calmly unless provoked. Slightly more aggressive than elephants but slower to anger than mammoths, loxorosas are often calm, level-headed animals who are content with eating aquatic vegetation all day. Unlike most proboscids, the loxorosa is mostly solitary, occasionally forming groups of two to three individuals who travel and play with one another like elephants would.

{@bold Vegetal Symbiosis.} The environment the loxorosa inhabit have led to an evolutionary pairing between the loxorosa and various species of plant matter. The plant matter grows within the loxorosa’s shaggy fur, entangling itself to get a better grip. In exchange for frequent time in the sun along with watering and rich fertilizer, the plant matter excretes an extremely powerful acidic compound that can melt most materials with ease, targeting them at the cellular level. The only exception to this corrosive property is anything carrying the loxorosa’s genetic material, which is practically immune to most forms of corrosion. Loxorosas cover their tusks with mold and vines in order to inflict a corrosive strike to anything that dares cross it.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The luminous eel can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every six hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the luminous eel has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Static Shock
entries: The luminous eel's body generates a potent static charge. A creature that touches or makes a successful melee attack against the eel takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: As a bonus action, the luminous eel sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light in an additional 10 ft. This effect persists until the eel ends it with a bonus action.

trait.name: Abyssal Camouflage
entries: The luminous eel has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in the dark.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The luminous eel makes two attacks; one with its bite and one with its tail slap.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) lightning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition paralyzed} for {@dice 1d4} rounds. The target can repeat the save on the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the target is immune to lightning damage, it can't be {@condition paralyzed}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage and the target is pushed up to 10 feet away.

action.name: Flash {@recharge}
entries: The luminous eel flashes its bio-luminescent organs in a blinding display of light in a 30-foot radius. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of their next turn.

bonus.name: Lure
entries: While hidden or obscured by darkness, the luminous eel can use the lure on its head to create a series of mesmerizing flashes of light. Any creature that can see the lure must make make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} for 1 minutes by the eel or until the eel harms the creature. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the creature may only use its turn to move towards the lure.

{@italic In the darkest abyssal depths of the sea, a lone, dancing light bobs in the blackness of the void. A lost dolphin, separated from its pod, approaches the light, charmed by its rhythmic movements. Enchanted by the dancing orb, it doesn’t notice as several patches of eerie blue illuminate a massive creature poised directly behind the light. As crackling electricity dances around the bio-luminescent beast, the dolphin is too late to escape as the lure is extinguished and a massive pair of jaws come lunging toward it from the darkness.}

{@bold Darkness Dwellers.} The abyssal-dwelling luminous eel is a massive beast, reaching lengths of 20 feet on average. Most of their lives are spent in the darkest depths of the ocean or in lightless sea caves, hunting anything it perceives to be edible. The eels only venture to the surface twice in their lifetimes, and exclusively during violent oceanic storms. The first journey occurs just after an individual reaches sexual maturity, leading the eels to flock to beaches and coastal habitats in order to breed. It is generally during this event that most attacks occur, as large, dominant males will attack anything that it senses to be a threat. Rival males will strike each other with their long, lashing tails, attempting to knock each other into submission. The victor of these battles will then put on a glorious bio-luminescent display in order to attract a mate. After mating, females will devour the males and remain on the coast before returning to the sea at the storm’s conclusion. Roughly seven to eight months later, the females, having grown even larger than the males at this point in their lives, will return to the beach at which they mated, travelling inland to lay eggs and hunt. They prefer to find places with high levels of static electricity to lay their clutch. After laying, the eels will remain around the coast until the storm ends, at which point they will venture back into the ocean to die. The newborn eels will hatch roughly a week later, returning to the sea in order to begin the cycle anew.

{@bold Electrogenic Hunters:} Luminous eels prefer to hunt similarly to anglerfish, enthralling potential prey with their dancing lure before striking when the target is effectively harmless. The bio-luminescent organs lining their bodies also act similarly to the specialized organs of an electric eel (Main organ, Sachs’ organ, and Hunter’s organ), allowing for electroreception, electrolocation, and, to a much more intense extent, electrocution. The eel channels static electricity via the sodium-potassium exchanger, which maintains a voltage imbalance between the inside of the eel’s cells and their surroundings. The exchanger is said to be “electrogenic” because it removes three sodium ions for every two ions of potassium it allows in. The eel’s bio-luminescent organs have the highest concentration of electrolyte exchangers, with an uneven distribution throughout the rest of its body. Luminous eels have several thousand of these exchanger cells stacked atop one another, capable of a discharge of over 900 V.

{@bold Rogue Males:} When most members of the species are breeding, a select few male individuals will travel too far in search of a mate, eventually getting trapped inland as the storm passes. These rogue males aren’t slaughtered by their mates and are thus left to grow and hunt as they please. These eels lair in coastal caves with various pools of water readily available to allow for easy access to the sea. Transitioning to a more terrestrial lifestyle, these rogue males claim large territories, ranging anywhere from 20 to 40 square miles. They defend these territories ferociously, patrolling them vigilantly. They are nocturnal predators, behaving similarly to will-o-wisps. They will lure unsuspecting travelers and other creatures close enough to be shocked and devoured. In fact, in areas where will-o’-wisps are present, the rogue males will often mistake their lights for a challenging male, charging towards the tiny undead with immense prejudice.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The lupilisk has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The lupilisk has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the lupilisk's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} and {@condition restrained} while {@condition poisoned} in this way. The creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. If the save fails again, the creature is {@condition petrified} for 24 hours. At that time, it can repeat the saving throw, becoming permanently {@condition petrified} on a failure or ending the effect on a success.
{@i “If you find a statue in the wild with its mouth open in a scream, flee. Best case, it’s an artist working out their twisted ideas. Worst case, you’ll be a statue soon.”}

{@b Petrifying Predators.} The fiendish lupilisks can be found in woodland areas or amid an infernal army. their impressive strength and agility, as well as their size, makes them perfect mounts for infernal cavalry. And their keen instincts mark them as an apex predator. Lupilisks prefer to play with their food, chasing and tormenting it before turning it to stone. The lupilisk then eats the rocky remains. As with a basilisk, the lupilisk’s gullet reverses the petrification, turning stone to flesh once it reaches the creature’s stomach.

{@b Family Pack.} In the wild, lupilisks gather in packs. A dominant elder couple leads the pack, and other pack members are that couple’s offspring. Juvenile males seek mates from other packs, while juvenile females decide whether to take visiting males as mates. A lupilisk pack is a family, its adult children leaving to form new packs.
{@b Trained Mounts.} A lupilisk is more beast than fiend. They’re aggressive and cruel, but they can be controlled if trained with firm discipline.

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the magmadile or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Earthen Crawl
entries: The magmadile can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. Unless the magmadile chooses otherwise, it doesn't disturb the material it moves through. If it has a creature {@condition grappled}, it can't choose not to disturb the material.

trait.name: Molten Dive
entries: The magmadile can only use its swim speed within lava, as it's too hot and dense to swim through water. When in water, molten magma excretes from the cracks in its rocky hide, hardening into stone. The magmadile creates a platform of obsidian within a radius of 10 feet, centered on itself. The magmadile can burrow through this obsidian if it has enough depth.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The magmadile can hold its breath for 30 minutes.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the magmadile can't bite another target or use its lava plume.

action.name: Lava Plume {@recharge 5}
entries: The magmadile expectorates a flowing gout of scorching magma in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) bludgeoning damage and 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage, and is pushed 30 feet away from the magmadile and knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.

The lava remains active on the ground where it lands, spreading an additional 5 feet from where it originates. The lava is difficult terrain, and it immolates unattended flammable objects and melts others. Any creature that starts its turn in the lava takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage. The lava remains active for {@dice 1d4} rounds before solidifying, grappling any creature trapped within it upon a failed {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. Any creature {@condition grappled} by the lava can escape with a successful {@dc 16} Strength saving throw.

{@italic Within the molten pools of boiling lava scattering the material plane, a massive beast lurks. With its molten, rock-like hide, a magmadile resembles a large chunk of igneous rock floating within the magma. This can prove to be a fatal mistake for many, as a magmadile is instead a massive reptilian predator that burns hotter than the lava it inhabits.}

{@bold Internal Flame.} A magmadile’s main food source is firenewts, attracted to the internal heat they possess. As a result, these reptiles adapted to survive within the harsh volcanic areas in which they inhabit in order to better hunt their preferred prey. As a result of preying on firenewts, magmadiles have consumed their special alchemical mixture enough times to truly incorporate it within their bodies, allowing them to withstand impossible temperatures and vomit boiling magma. \u000b     A miniature volcano that sprouts from their back erupts whenever they exhale lava, solidifying and hardening the magmadile’s rock-like scales. As a result of these scales, a magmadile can weigh up to 2 tons. As magmadiles are too dense and heavy to swim, they excrete magma from the cracks in their scales to solidify and create land. As a result, magmadiles can wreak havoc on wetlands and large bodies of water, transforming miles of water into dry land in just a matter of hours.

{@bold Underground Hunters.} While magmadiles are commonly seen carelessly drifting down flowing rivers of lava, this is one of the few times they can ever be seen. Magmadiles tunnel through the earth as they hunt, utilizing their intense, scorching magma to rapidly melt and recreate earth and stone, propelling themselves through the ground with their powerful tails. Similarly to bulettes, magmadiles attack from below, sensing the vibrations through the soil and rock from the unaware creatures above the surface. However, unlike the bulette, magmadiles are primarily ambush predators, leaving the earth around them undisturbed as they tunnel.

Magmadiles hunt similarly to their semi-aquatic cousins, waiting just under the surface of the earth to catch potential prey off-guard. They often follow just inches below whatever they intend to devour, attempting to gauge its size and strength through the vibrations it gives off as it walks. When the prey animal stops, the magmadile will burst from the ground, grasping the unsuspecting creature in its scorching jaws before dragging it below the soil to be devoured, leaving the surface completely undisturbed.

trait.name: Concussive Blow
entries: When the magniventris doesn't have disadvantage on its attack roll, it can choose to make a melee attack with disadvantage. On a hit, it deals normal damage. It does not push a targeted creature, but the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the start of the magniventris’ next turn.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The magniventris deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Stable
entries: Whenever an effect knocks the magniventris {@condition prone}, it can make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw to avoid being knocked {@condition prone}. A {@condition prone} magniventris is upside down. To stand up, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity check on its turn and then use all its movement for that turn.

trait.name: Stubborn
entries: When the magniventris fails a Constitution saving throw that deals damage, it takes only half damage. On a success, it takes no damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 6d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and pushed up to 10 feet away.

The magniventris is closely related to the ankylosaurus, sharing many of the same traits. The magniventris magnifies these traits exponentially, with hulking size, greater bulk, and a more devastating tail club.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The mahoru can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The mahoru has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The mahoru has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the mahoru's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The mahoru has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that isn't at maximum hit points.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Roar
entries: When a mahoru roars all creatures with hearing within 30 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of the mahoru's next turn. If the target fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it's also {@condition paralyzed} for the same duration. A target that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the Roar of all mahoru for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Vorpal Bite
entries: A mahoru's saw-like jaws excel at dismembering prey. When the mahoru scores a critical hit, the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or lose an appendage. Roll {@dice 1d12} on the following table for the result:
1–2: right hand
3–4: left hand
5–6: right foot
7–8: left foot
9: right forearm
10: left forearm
11: right lower leg
12: left lower leg

{@i I saw no more terrible beast on all my journeys north than the mahoru. The white bears had their aloof majesty, the lindwurm serpentine grace, but the monster that gnawed away the pack ice beneath our feet and savaged any who fell into the water was a thing of nightmare. The men it snatched were torn apart, like rags in the mouth of a rabid dog.}
A hybrid of fish and mammal, a mahoru is eight feet long and looks like a small orca with a serpentine neck and seal-like head.

entries.name: Valuable Teeth and Fur
entries: Their heavy jaws are filled with triangular, serrated teeth adept at tearing flesh and sundering bone. Their white and black fur is highly prized for its warmth and waterproof qualities. Their pectoral fins feature stubby, claw-tipped paws. Skraeling use the mahoru's fangs to make arrowheads or tooth-studded clubs, and the mahoru is a totem beast for many northern tribes.

entries.name: Iceberg Hunters
entries: Relatives of the bunyip, mahoru prowl northern coasts and estuaries, hunting among the fragmenting pack ice each summer. They lurk beneath the surface, catching swimmers chunks or lurching up onto the ice to break or tilt it and send prey tumbling into the water. When necessary, they stalk beaches and riverbanks in search of carrion or unwary victims.

entries.name: Work in Pairs and Packs
entries: Mahoru work together in mated pairs to corral everything from fish and seals to larger prey like kayaking humans and even polar bears. They gnaw at ice bridges and the frozen surface of lakes and rivers to create fragile patches that plunge unwary victims into their waiting jaws.

trait.name: Pack Formation
entries: If the malcinder is within 10 feet of a hostile creature, each ally within 30 feet of the malcinder has advantage on attack rolls against the hostile target.

trait.name: Running Leap
entries: With a 10-foot running start, the malcinder can long jump up to 25 feet.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the malcinder moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the malcinder can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The malcinder has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell.

trait.name: Fiery Body
entries: A creature that touches the malcinder or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The malcinder makes two attacks, only one of which can be a bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 6 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} ({@dc 14}) and {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tail Flame
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft. or range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) fire damage.
{@i “A shadowy form moves silently toward its prey, stalking with precision. Sudden flames erupt as the malcinder roars and leaps into the air to crush its target to the ground.”}

{@b Infernal Hunters.} Long ago, a fiendish species of feline-like fiends escaped the Netherworld, forming small prides across every region. These creatures suppressed their infernal nature to the point where they shed their fiendish traits entirely, becoming lion-like
{@b Born in Flames.} When a malcinder attacks, its body hardens like cooling lava, and flames glow through its skull. It harnesses this infernal fire within its whiplike tail to hurl flame.
{@b Burning Leader.} The strongest of malcinders leads a pack. This alpha is the largest in the group and the best hunter. A malcinder alpha draws attention so the pack can attack from all sides.

trait.name: Watery Lurker
entries: The crocodile has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks while submerged in water.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The crocodile can hold its breath for 30 minutes.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the crocodile can't bite another target.

action.name: Death Roll
entries: {@atk mw} one target it has {@condition grappled}. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d10 + 4}) piercing damage. If the maneater crocodile and the target are both underwater, this attack is considered a critical hit.

The maneater crocodile is a large and opportunistic hypercarnivorous apex predator. It ambushes most of its prey and then drowns or swallows it whole. It is capable of prevailing over almost any animal that enters its territory, including other apex predators such as sharks, various reptiles, birds, and mammals. Maneater crocodiles have immensely powerful jaws which they use to crush anything that presents itself to be a meal.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The Maw of the Great Hyena has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the Maw of the Great Hyena's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The Maw of the Great Hyena has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Maw of the Great Hyena makes two bite attacks. If both attacks hit the target and the target is a creature, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition frightened} it takes an additional 22 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage. This attack ignores damage resistance.

action.name: Call the Clan (Recharges on a Long Rest)
entries: The Maw of the Great Hyena magically duplicates itself, creating up to three spiritual replicas at a point it can see within 60 feet of itself that is not being occupied by another creature. Each replica uses the statistics of the Maw of the Great Hyena except it has 24 hit points and does not have access to Call the Clan, Cackling Cacophony, or multiattack actions. The Great Hyena can communicate telepathically with a replica as long as they are on the same plane of existence. The Great Hyena can innately see, hear, and smell whatever any of its replicas sense. The replicas act as allies of the Great Hyena and obey its telepathic commands, taking their turns immediately after the Great Hyena. The replicas remain until killed or dismissed by the Great Hyena as a bonus action. Slain or dismissed replicas vaporize into warming orange wisps of flame.

action.name: Cackling Cacophony {@recharge 5}
entries: The Maw of the Great Hyena emits a maddening cackle of blazing air in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. In addition, each creature in that area that isn't {@condition deafened} must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of the Great Hyena until the end of the hyena's next turn. While a creature is {@condition frightened} in this way, its speed is halved, and it is {@condition incapacitated}.

While most individuals only view hyenas as the tainted offspring of Yeenoghu, they are still wild beasts, and aspects of nature still take hold of them on occasion. Roaming the savannas and deserts is a fierce hyena the size of a horse, cackling and snarling amidst the intense heat that radiates off of it. The Maw of the Great Hyena's abilities are almost identical to the Fang of the Great Wolf's, although their cold-oriented abilities and immunities are replaced with fire.

trait.name: Towering Strength
entries: The mirepod can lift up to 1,000,000 pounds, or 500 tons.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The mirepod can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Unrivaled Power
entries: The mirepod's melee attacks are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance and immunity.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mirepod makes two slashing slam attacks.

action.name: Slashing Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) bludgeoning or slashing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. Instead of doing damage, the mirepod can grapple the target (escape {@dc 21}). While the target is {@condition grappled}, it is also {@condition restrained}. The mirepod has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

action.name: Boulder
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}44 ({@damage 10d6 + 9}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Throw
entries: The mirepod throws one creature it has {@condition grappled}. The creature is thrown a distance of {@dice 2d6 x 10} feet in the direction the mirepod chooses, falls {@condition prone}, and takes 20 ({@damage 2d12 + 9}) bludgeoning damage (plus falling damage if they are thrown into a chasm or off a cliff). The mirepod can throw a creature up to Huge size. Small creatures are thrown twice as far, but the damage is the same.

action.name: Sweep {@recharge 5}
entries: The mirepod sweeps its limbs in a wide arc. Each creature in a 10 foot radius must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 35 ({@damage 10d8 + 18}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Fountain {@recharge 4}
entries: The mirepod exhales a jet of pressurized water in a line that is 90 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 18 ({@damage 5d6}) bludgeoning damage and is pushed up to 30 feet away from the mirepod and knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Collide
entries: If the mirepod starts its turn with a target {@condition grappled}, it can slam the target into the ground as a bonus action. The creature must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 3d10 + 9}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. This doesn't end the {@condition grappled} condition on the target.
Mirepods are massive and extremely strong crustaceans that use their overwhelming power to crush anything in their way.

{@b Ambushers.} Mirepods have grown to incredible sizes over time in order to hunt terrestrial prey that lounge on cliffs and shores. Mirepods use their extreme strength to grab and drown anything in reach, fulfilling a niche similar to crocodiles.

{@b Earth-Shattering Battles.} Bull mirepods are known to fight violently for mating rights, sacrificing life and limb to achieve victory. Thrill-seekers oftentimes seek out two bulls clashing just to watch from afar, admiring the sheer brutality displayed between the two rivals. Two bulls attempt to wrestle each other to the ground, though their extreme strength makes injuries extremely common.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The mothman regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point and isn't in direct sunlight. If the mothman takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the mothman's next turn.

trait.name: Overwhelmed by Light
entries: If the mothman is directly exposed to sunlight, it takes 10 radiant damage at the start of each of its turns, and suffers disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws made while in the sunlight. In addition, its speed is halved.

trait.name: Energy Capacity
entries: The mothman has several abilities that give it temporary hit points. These hit points last for 8 hours and can be added onto. If the mothman has over 100 temporary hit points, it instantly loses all of them and takes that much damage.

trait.name: Radiant Vulnerability
entries: Whenever the mothman takes radiant damage, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Unless it is {@condition prone} or {@condition restrained}, the mothman makes two attacks with its talons and one with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the additional damage taken, and the mothman gains temporary hit points equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. Undead targets take the maximum amount of necrotic damage even if they are resistant to or immune to necrotic damage, as the mothman saps the necrotic energy from their veins.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d4 + 6}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}) and {@condition restrained} if it is a creature that is Large or smaller. If it is grappling a creature, the mothman can't attack another creature with its talons.

action.name: Energy Beam
entries: The mothman expends 25 of its temporary hit points, shooting a line of energy that is 60 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 52 ({@damage 8d12}) force damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

action.name: Overcharge
entries: The mothman expels all of its energy at once in a destructive and violent burst of power. The mothman expends all of its current total temporary hit points, up to a maximum of 100. For every 5 hit points expended, the mothman deals 6 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage in a radius equal to the number of temporary hit points spent, up to a maximum of 110 ({@damage 20d10}) force damage in a 100-foot-radius centered on itself. Each creature in the mothman's overcharge radius must succeed on a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw, taking half as much damage and being {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn on a failed save and half as much damage on a successful one.

bonus.name: Heat Siphon
entries: The mothman targets a nonliving source of heat within 60 feet of itself that it can see. It then extinguishes up to 15 square feet of the source, gaining 5 temporary hit points for each 5 foot square affected.

bonus.name: Overhaul
entries: The mothman expends 5 of its temporary hit points to double its flying speed until the end of its next turn.

reaction.name: Arcane Siphon
entries: If the mothman is targeted by a spell of 6th level or lower that it can see, it can use its reaction to consume the magic instead. It then gains temporary hit points equal to the spell's level x 5.

reaction.name: Sonic Siphon
entries: The mothman targets a source of sound within 60 feet of itself that it can see and hear. It then uses its reaction to silence the source of sound for 1 round, gaining 5 temporary hit points.
{@i From the darkness, a large, winged creature perches high in a tree. It focuses ravenously on the glow of a fire far in the distance, its two massive, vibrant red eyes glowing in the dark.}
Mothmen are hulking humanoid creatures that are distantly related to umber hulks. With wide, feathered wings and two piercing red eyes, the mothman looks like a mix between an owl, a moth, and a man.

{@b Energy Vampires.} In a strange and questionable form of convergent evolution, “mothmen,” as they are called by those familiar with them, began to take on aspects of vampires in order to prey on pure energy. Mothmen are, as a result, extremely vulnerable to direct sunlight and pure radiance, to the point where being caught in the sun can kill them within minutes. However, this has allowed them to master the night, becoming apex predators of the dark. To fit their nocturnal lifestyle, the eyes of mothmen became large and extremely sensitive, able to pierce through any darkness. They use the cover of the night to soar silently through the air, searching for any forms of energy to be feasted upon. Mothmen search for any form of energy they can find, though usually these sources are heat or sound. After devouring a sufficient amount of energy, mothmen become supernaturally powerful, able to fire beams of energy from their eyes or move at incredible speeds.

{@b Ravenous.} To support their diet of pure energy, mothmen have extremely high metabolisms. They heal from injuries extremely quickly and are completely immune to most toxins, the effects of cold, and even necrosis. As a result, they are constantly seeking out and hunting for more energy, making them highly aggressive if met with resistance. While it is not common for mothmen to prey on living creatures, a starving mothman will attack and drain the blood from other organisms. They are especially dangerous to spellcasters, devouring the energy used to cast spells and rendering the magic entirely inert.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The narshark has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Magical Horn
entries: The narshark's horn can be attacked and severed (AC 18; hp 5; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage) or destroyed (hp 15). If its horn is severed, the narshark loses its flying speed, loses 4 ({@damage 1d8}) hp at the start of each of its turns, and goes into a frenzy. While in a frenzy, the narshark has advantage on bite attack rolls and attack rolls against it have advantage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage. If the creature isn't an undead or a construct, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or lose 2 ({@damage 1d4}) hp at the start of each of its turns as one of the shark's teeth chips off into the wound. Any creature can take an action to stanch the wound by removing the tooth. The wound also closes and the tooth pops out if the target receives magical healing.

Almost blending in with the sky, this creature looks like a large shark with cerulean-hued skin and incredibly long pectoral fins that it uses to sail through the air like a bird. Its mouth is filled with several rows of vicious teeth, and an ivory horn emerges from the top of its head.

entries.name: Aerial Predators
entries: A narshark is a creature that resembles a cross between a shark and a narwhal with dark blue skin, long serrated teeth, and a horn growing from its brow. Like many sharks, the narshark is a rapacious predator, hunting birds through the sky as a shark hunts fish. While it lacks the keen nose of most predators, the narshark has excellent eyesight and can pick out details at great distances. While narsharks are dangerous predators, they are seldom top of the aerial food chain and face fierce competition from {@creature giant eagle|mm|giant eagles}, {@creature hippogriff|mm|hippogriffs}, and {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}. They are also frequently hunted by {@creature griffon|mm|griffins}, {@creature wyvern|mm|wyverns}, and {@creature roc|mm|rocs} that easily pluck them out of the sky with their greater maneuverability and speed.

entries.name: Magical Horns
entries: The narshark gains its ability to fly from its magical horn. The horn can be severed from a living narshark, but doing so drives it into a panicked rage as it attempts to slay all those around it. Strangely, narsharks never use their horns in combat, possibly in fear of accidentally breaking them. A narshark's horn is commonly used in the creation of magic items that grant flight, and narsharks are often the target of hunters seeking to turn a profit.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: Ol' Chazz can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Underwater Propulsion
entries: When Ol' Chazz is underwater, it can take the Dash action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Coral Shell
entries: Ol' Chazz has a shell made entirely out of a thriving coral structure. While Ol' Chazz's coral shell is active, it gains the following benefits:
- Ol' Chazz has an Armor Class of 18.
- Ol' Chazz has its movement speed reduced by 20 feet.
- Creatures that hit Ol' Chazz with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage.
- Ol' Chazz has access to the {@i Summon Swarm} action.
When Ol' Chazz is reduced to less than half of its maximum hit points for the first time, its coral shell is destroyed. The shell regenerates over the course of a long rest.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Ol' Chazz makes two attacks; one with its bite and one with its tail. It can't make both attacks against the same target.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and Ol' Chazz can't bite another target.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Summon Swarm {@recharge 5}
entries: Ol' Chazz summons a {@creature swarm of quippers|MM} that forms in a space within 20 feet of it. The swarm acts as an ally of Ol' Chazz and takes its turn immediately after it. The swarm disperses after 1 minute. It can't use the Summon Swarm action while its coral shell is destroyed.

action.name: Slowing Poison {@recharge 6}
entries: Ol' Chazz targets one or more creatures it can see within 10 feet of it. Each target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw against this poison. On a failed save, a target can't use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can't make more than one attack on its turn. In addition, the target can take either an action or a bonus action on its turn, not both. These effects last for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target succeeds on this saving throw, it is immune to Ol' Chazz's Slowing Poison for the next 24 hours.

Originating from the lagoons and coasts of Saltmarsh, “Ol’ Chazz” is a local legend and tourist attraction. Despite its ferocious appearance, Chazz is not known to feed on or attack watergoers, primarily feeding on fish and small marine mammals. Chazz has the general shape of a large plesiosaur, though it has long, catfish-like whiskers and nematocysts, giving it a jellyfish-like exterior. The stinging cells present in Chazz’s skin allow it to secrete a dangerous and debilitating poison, allowing it to paralyze entire schools of fish to devour.

Ol’ Chazz is known to house a massive coral reef on its back. Chazz is known to share a three-way symbiotic relationship with two other organisms; the reef and the school of carnivorous fish that inhabit the reef. The reef grows on Chazz’s back in order to maximize food consumption and to better reproduce. The fish receives a home, a steady source of food, and protection. Chazz receives protection from the extremely durable and razor sharp “shell” of coral that resides on its back. In addition, the school that resides inside the reef is hyperaggressive towards anything that grows too close to Chazz, fighting tooth and fin for their home.

trait.name: Flinging Charge
entries: If the pachycephalosaurus moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, that target takes an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage and it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be thrown up to 15 feet away and knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Sure-Footed
entries: The pachycephalosaurus has advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Vigilant
entries: If a creature moves from the pachycephalosaurus in any way, the pachycephalosaurus can make one attack of opportunity against the target.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

The pachycephalosaurus is a bipedal herbivore with an extremely thick skull dome, which they use to defend themselves. Male pachycephalosaurs also use them to clash with each other as a form of rivalry.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Paka Paka's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the Paka Paka moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the Paka Paka can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The Paka Paka has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Paka Paka makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is {@condition prone}, this attack scores a critical hit.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage. If the Paka Paka hits the same target with two claw attacks on the same turn, the target is also {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Blink {@recharge 4}
entries: The Paka Paka magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 90 feet to an unoccupied space it can see. Before or after teleporting, the Paka Paka can make one claw attack. The Paka Paka can bring any creature it is grappling with it.

bonus.name: Feline Agility
entries: The Paka Paka can take the Dash or Disengage action.

reaction.name: Ferocious Bite
entries: If a creature is {@condition grappled} by the Paka Paka at the end of the creature's turn, the Paka Paka makes a bite attack against it with advantage.

{@italic Slinking through the darkness of the Sloefire, a cat-like creature stalks its prey. Its skeletal front-limbs and skull reflect the pale moonlight as it pokes its head out from the dark, zeroing in on a lone deer. With a flash, purple flames erupt from its back, and the feline is gone, suddenly reappearing on the deer’s back.}
The Paka Paka is a legendary creature native to the Sloefire bog that uses an innate magical connection to teleport freely.

{@bold Blinking Predator.} This big cat is thought to have been one of the several species of feline that used to reside within the Sloefire bog before the Calamity. Afterwards, arcane radiation began to tamper with one individual cat, causing it to change exponentially. The Paka Paka has skeletal forelimbs and an animated skull, with piercing purple eyes within its sockets. A ghastly flame burns at the tip of its tail like the tuft of hair at the end of lion’s. Ages later, the Paka Paka persists, hunting with methods unlike any other animal. The Paka Paka has an extraordinary talent that allows it to “blink” effortlessly, similar to the blink dogs of the Feywild.  The Paka Paka can temporarily phase in and out of existence to some extent, giving the illusion of blinking between location to location. When blinking, ghostly purple flames erupt from its neck and back like the mane of a horse, sending violet embers scattering through the air. Unlike blink dogs, the Paka Paka can teleport while blinking, allowing it to clear expansive terrain in seconds.

{@bold Ethereal Wanderer.} The Paka Paka has a connection to the Ethereal Plane unique only to this animal. Its extraordinarily keen vision allows it to peer into the Ethereal Plane to see the unseen, making it impossible to escape. When resting, the Paka Paka will often reside in the Ethereal Plane to avoid potential predators, though this Ethereal connection is not absolute. As a result, the Paka Paka may appear to “flicker” in and out of existence every few seconds, giving off a disorienting appearance.

{@bold Legendary Beast.} With its skeletal features and predatory prowess, the Paka Paka quickly became a creature of interest to the remaining sentient inhabitants of the Sloefire bog, most prominently the lizardfolk tribe. Its likeness can be seen in murals, paintings, and art produced by them, and it is revered by many. As a result, its legendary status is rewarded with offerings of riches, delicacies, and totems. An individual who has seen the Paka Paka is regarded as extremely fortunate.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d12 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Flame Hurl
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Fire Cloud {@recharge 6}
entries: The parasaurolophus exhales fire in a 15-foot cone. Each target in that cone takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw.
The parasaurolophus is a large grazing herbivore that travels in great herds. When threatened, the parasaurolophus can exhale a cloud of fire at anything harassing it.

trait.name: Radioactive Aura
entries: At the start of each of the radiant carnotaurus' turns, each creature within 20 feet of it must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the radiant carnotaurus moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the radiant carnotaurus can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The radiant carnotaurus has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The radiant carnotaurus makes one gore attack and one bite attack.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or become infected with the corpse cough disease (see the Corpse Cough trait).

action.name: Irradiated Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The radiant carnotaurus' exhales radioactive fire in a 30-foot cone, bathing it in blazing purple flame. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) radiant damage and is infected with the corpse cough disease (see the Corpse Cough trait). On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't infected with the disease.

variant.name: Corpse Cough
entries: Those who fail a saving throw against the radiant carnotaurus' Irradiated Breath or Bite attack become infected with the corpse cough disease. The infected creature can't benefit from short or long rests due to a constant, wet cough. The infected creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw each day or take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the radiant damage taken. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. Additionally, the infected creature has disadvantage on Strength and Constitution saving throws, attack rolls, and skill checks. These reductions lasts until the target is cured of the disease with a {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic. If the infected creature comes into physical contact with another living creature or is within 10 feet of one before the disease is cured, the uninfected creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or also become infected with the disease. The newly-infected is afflicted with a constant, wet cough within hours of infection, but the disease's full effects don't manifest until {@dice 1d4} days later. Corpse cough is so named due to the smell of the cough as the infected creature's lungs become necrotic.
{@i This muscular archosaur has a pair of wide horns, like those of a bull, and a reddish tint in its eyes that emits a sickening radiance.}

{@b Irradiated Predator.} Known to be a bringer of incredible sickness, radiant carnotauruses are sought after for their horns and their teeth, both believed to have powerful curative properties. The bones of a radiant carnotaurus are highly radioactive and can prove fatal to any creature that strays too close to it.

{@b Wilderness Wanderer.} Radiant carnotaureses travel across entire continents, never staying in one area for more than a few seasons. They are swift and powerful hunters that use their overwhelming bulk to knock prey to the ground and rip them to pieces.

{@b Grisly Signs.} Travelers should take warning when approaching the mutilated remains of an animal in an isolated area. Anything killed by a radiant carnotaurus becomes a beacon of radiation, and can irradiate other creatures that draw too close.

trait.name: Aura of Wrath
entries: Provided the red quoxxarie isn't {@condition incapacitated}, any creature (including another red quoxxarie) that starts its turn within 30 feet of one or more red quoxxaries can grant itself advantage on attack rolls until the start of its next turn. Attack rolls against the creature also have advantage until then. If the creature is hostile to the quoxxarie and uses this aura, the creature also has disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma checks until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the red quoxxarie moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its ram on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d10}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The red quoxxarie has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The red quoxxarie's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the red quoxxarie can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The red quoxxarie makes one ram attack and one hooves attack.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12({@damage 2d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Get the Horns
entries: If the white quoxxarie takes damage from one creature within 40 feet of it, the quoxxarie can take the Disengage action and move up to half its speed toward that creature. If the creature is then within reach, the quoxxarie can make a ram attack against it with advantage on the attack roll.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The ridleyblood kongamato doesn't provoke an opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The ridleyblood kongamato deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Carrier
entries: The ridleyblood kongamoto can move at its full speed when dragging a creature it has {@condition grappled}. In addition, if the ridleyblood kongamoto grapples a Large or smaller creature, the target has disadvantage on its escape attempts.

trait.name: Fire Knitting
entries: The ridleyblood kongamato's blood boils eternally. When the ridleyblood kongamato takes damage of any type but psychic, each creature within 5 feet of the kongamato takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) fire damage. In addition, any creature {@condition grappled} by the ridleyblood kongamato takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) fire damage at the start of its turn.

trait.name: Sadistic Strike
entries: The ridleyblood kongamoto scores a critical hit on a roll of 19-20.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ridleyblood kongamoto uses Crush. It then makes one bite attack, two claw attacks, and one piercing tail attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}34 ({@damage 4d10 + 8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d6 + 8}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). While {@condition grappled}, the target is {@condition restrained}. The ridleyblood kongamato has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target at a time.

action.name: Piercing Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 25 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) piercing damage, and the target is impaled. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}) and {@condition restrained} until the grapple ends, at which point the creature is forced to make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. A creature loses 13 ({@damage 2d12}) hit points due to blood loss on a failed save, or half as many hit points on a successful one as long as the creature has blood (or some other analogous fluid) to lose. The ridleyblood kongamato can have one target impaled at a time.

action.name: Crush
entries: The ridleyblood kongamato crushes one creature {@condition grappled} by it. The target must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 27 ({@damage 6d8}) bludgeoning damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage, can't breathe, speak, or cast spells, and begins suffocating. On a success, the target takes half the bludgeoning damage and suffers none of the other effects. Until this crushing grapple ends (escape {@dc 16}), the target takes 13 ({@damage 3d8}) bludgeoning damage at the start of each of its turns. The ridleyblood kongamato can crush up to two Large or smaller targets or one Huge target at a time.

action.name: Agonizing Blaze {@recharge 5}
entries: The ridleyblood kongamato exhales fire in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area takes 91 ({@damage 16d8}) fire damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw. Each creature in that area must also succeed on a {@dc 21} Wisdom saving throw or go on a rampage for 1 minute. A rampaging creature must attack the nearest living creature or smash some object smaller than itself if no creature can be reached with a single move. A rampaging creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

legendary.name: Rush (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The ridleyblood kongamato moves up to its flying speed.

legendary.name: Drag
entries: If the ridleyblood kongamato is adjacent to a solid surface (up to 15 feet away), it can move up to its flying speed without provoking opportunity attacks. Each creature {@condition grappled} by it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or take 4 ({@damage 1d6}) slashing damage for every 10 feet moved across the surface. Any creature in the ridleyblood kongamato's way when it moves must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 2d10}) bludgeoning damage and be shunted 5 feet away from the ridleyblood kongamato.

legendary.name: Devour
entries: The ridleyblood kongamato makes a bite attack against a creature in range. If the attack hits, the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw or take an additional 12 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The ridleyblood kongamato regains an amount of hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt.
{@i The kongamato is an evolutionary holdover, a large pterodactyl with avian traits, such as emergent feathers and long, beaklike jaws.}

entries.name: Boat Breaker
entries: Its name means "breaker of boats," and as that implies, this creature systematically destroys the small vessels of those who come too close to its perch. No one knows what motivates this form of attack, although some sages suppose that the kongamato mistakes canoes for large prey like hippopotami or crocodiles.

entries.name: Spoken in Whispers
entries: For some tribes, kongamatos present a terrible threat, and they speak in whispers about them, fearing that mention of the beasts could attract their wrath. In some cases, evil priests and cultists summon these beasts as their servitors and use them to terrify villagers.

entries.name: Maneaters
entries: Kongamatos that have eaten human flesh develop a preference for it. These maneaters perform nightly raids on small towns, snatching children and Small humanoids with their claws and flying away.

spellcasting.name: Sand Manipulation
headerEntries: The sandwurm's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit). The sandwurm can cast the following spells without any components.
footerEntries: Each spell cast in this way is made out of and targets only sand, though the effects of the spell do not change. The sandwurm can target its own Sand Vortex if the spell requires sand to be present.

Each spell cast in this way takes effect instantly, though it decreases the radius of the sandwurm's Sand Vortex by 20 feet. If Sand Vortex's radius decreases to 50 feet, the sandwurm loses its magic resistance and its immunities to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage become resistances. If Sand Vortex ceases, the Sandwurm loses all of its resistances.

trait.name: Tunneler
entries: The wurm can burrow through solid rock at half its burrow speed and leaves a 10-foot-diameter tunnel in its wake.

trait.name: Sand Vortex
entries: The sandwurm is surrounded by a thick, red sand that extends within 100 feet of itself in a dense cloud. The cloud moves with the sandwurm, heavily obscuring the area around it. The sandwurm knows the exact location of any object or creature in its vortex, and anything inside of the vortex can't benefit from any effect that would hide it from the sandwurm. Each creature that starts its turn within the sandwurm's vortex suffers from the following:
- The creature takes 3 slashing damage.
- The creature's speed is reduced by 10 feet.
- The target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of its current turn.

trait.name: Shattering Sands
entries: The sandwurm's Concentrate Sand deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The sandwurm has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Vitrification
entries: If the sandwurm takes fire damage, the sand around it partially solidifies into glass; it has disadvantage on all attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks and its speed is reduced by 20 feet until the end of its next turn. In addition, for every 10 fire damage dealt to the sandwurm, the radius of Sand Vortex decreases by 10 feet.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sandwurm attacks three times with Concentrate Sand. It then makes one bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 2d20 + 9}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the wurm. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the wurm, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the wurm's turns.

If the wurm takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the wurm must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the wurm. If the wurm dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Concentrate Sand
entries: The sandwurm concentrates the movement of its Sand Vortex, creating a dangerous and powerful force. The sandwurm launches a large column of hardened sand at a target it can see within 130 feet of it. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and fall {@condition prone}, taking half as much damage and not falling {@condition prone} on a successful save. The sandwurm can not use this attack if Sand Vortex is inactive.

action.name: Generate Sand
entries: The sandwurm regenerates 15 feet of Sand Vortex. This can not force Sand Vortex's radius to extend past 100 feet.

Sandwurms are the largest predators of Shefet, swimming through the sandy dunes like {@creature river serpent|PSA|serpents} through water. They are capable of amazing speed and can lift their lamprey-like heads far above the ground to snatch even flying creatures. But they can also lie in wait beneath the sands for years, until the slightest tremor alerts them to the presence of prey.

entries.name: The Desert Lands
entries: The desolate wilderness beyond the protection of the Hekma is largely uncharted. Immediately beyond the protective veil is a chaotic dune sea called Shefet, the Scouring Sands. The desert wears away at the edges of the fertile lands surrounding Naktamun, serving as a constant reminder that only the bounty and protection of the God-Pharaoh stand between the people of the city-state and a grisly death in the sands beyond. Beyond Shefet are parched, cracked expanses called Ramunap, the Broken Lands. The ruins of ancient civilizations are said to lie in the Broken Lands, though no one has ever explored such ruins and returned to Naktamun to tell of them.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the sarsaok moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 21 ({@damage 2d20}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Divine Horns
entries: The sarsaok's gore attack is magical and scores a critical hit on a roll of 18-20. In addition, its gore attack ignores the target's resistances to piercing or fire damage.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: Any creature that touches the sarsaok or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The sarsaok deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Sturdy
entries: When the sarsaok fails a Constitution saving throw that deals damage, it takes only half damage. On a success, it takes no damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sarsaok makes two attacks: one with its gore and two with its hooves.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 2d20 + 5}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Immolating Purge {@recharge 5}
entries: The sarsaok spews burning blood in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
This huge, six-horned, bull-like creature possesses a mane of writhing flames and shimmering metal skin.

entries.name: Creation of the Gods
entries: All sarsaok descend from Hadhayosh, a mighty celestial ox said to have been present at the creation of humanity. Scholars speculate the union of domestic or wild oxen with Hadhayosh produced the first sarsaok.

entries.name: Inhospitable Habitats
entries: The sarsaok dwell in areas of great heat and fire such as Volcanoes or other geologically active regions. In addition to consuming flora, they are known to drink liquid magma and graze on obsidian, pumice, or other volcanic rock.

entries.name: Peaceful Horror
