entries: Though of great size and strength, sarsaoks are peaceful herbivores similar in demeanor to wild oxen. When threatened, an entire herd attacks until the threat has ended.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The scarlet ibis' innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Death Curse
entries: When the scarlet ibis dies, all curses currently inflicted by the ibis become permanent and can be removed only by the {@spell remove curse} spell or other magic.

In addition, the creature that dealt the killing blow must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or become cursed with every option listed in the ibis's beak attack. A creature casting {@spell remove curse} on a creature cursed in this way must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or suffer the curses it just removed.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The scarlet ibis makes three attacks: one with its beak and two with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or become cursed. While cursed, the target suffers from one of the following effects of the scarlet ibis' choice:

items: The target has disadvantage on all attack rolls.
The target has disadvantage on all ability checks.
The target has disadvantage on all saving throws.
All attacks rolls against the target have advantage.
The target must make a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw at the start of each of its turns. If it fails, it wastes its action that turn doing nothing.
All saving throws and ability checks made with an ability score of the scarlet ibis' choice are reduced by {@dice 1d6}.

entries: A creature can have no more than one of each kind of curse on it at a time. The curses last for 24 hours or until removed by the {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) slashing damage.
{@i This gigantic marsh bird has blood-red feathers and a scythe-like beak. Its eyes shine with intelligence as it scans its surroundings.}
The scarlet ibis is a large bird native to the Sloefire known for their peculiar talent to inflict fatal misfortune on those they strike.

{@b Enchanted Birds.} Scarlet ibises are not inherently malevolent, and many visitors to the swamp assume they are simply overly large birds. However, their beaks bestow unluck on those touched or struck by them. The ibises usually reserve their cursed attacks as retribution for themselves, but swamp dwellers sometimes plea for the birds' intercession on those who have wronged them. Scarlet ibises have keen judgment to determine the worthiness of these requests.

Those who know about scarlet ibises and their terrible curses avoid killing the birds and typically warn others about the consequences of killing them. Less scrupulous folk instead encourage naïve travelers to destroy a scarlet ibis then pick off the travelers suffering from the aftereffects of combat with the birds.

{@b Untouchable Symbols.} Scarlet ibises are recognized as symbols of beauty and misfortune within the local lizardfolk tribe native to their home. Their dazzling crimson plumage is considered priceless to many, but the superstitious reptiles refuse to touch it in fear of the misfortune their death brings. The tribe will often observe an ibis from afar if one is spotted before offering it trinkets, which it often accepts.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The scitalis has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage.

action.name: Stunning Scales
entries: Each creature of the scitalis' choice that is within 60 feet of the scitalis and can see it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the scitalis' Stunning Scales for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The scitalis makes two attacks with its bite.

{@i The skin of this large snake is covered in an elegant pattern of intricate markings that scintillate with an eerie, supernatural brilliance. Its scales undulate a mesmerizing glamour as it slowly slithers forward.}

entries.name: Hypnotic Serpents
entries: The scitalis is a deadly serpentine beast that stuns its prey with the marvelous glimmer of its magically-variegated skin. Unlike most ophidians, these venomous hunters move rather slowly and rely on the stupefying effects of their otherworldly scales to capture the fleet of foot. With its prey adequately disabled, the scitalis languidly closes in to feast.

entries.name: Warm-bodied Wyrms
entries: Due to the strange quality of its iridescent skin, the scitalis is actually a warm-blooded reptile. This torpid supernatural monstrosity is cold-resistant and can be seen wandering as far as the frigid climes of the arctic. The snakeskin of the scitalis maintains some of its enchanted properties once shed and can often fetch handsome rewards from purveyors of the arcane.

entries.name: Eldritch Origins
entries: The provenance of the scitalis is a mystery as stupefying as its gleaming scales. Some sages speculate a draconic pedigree, while others claim this beautiful but deadly ophidian is a true child of Yig, the blasphemous Father of Serpents. Scitalis sightings are infrequent enough to fuel speculative and disquieting reports of variant breeds—glittering serpents with sinister spines, bat-like wings, or several sharp-toothed heads.
This creature's hide is required component for the {@item Cloak of Iridescence|CCodex}

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Shathou's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 20}, +12 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: Shathou can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: Shathou sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Shathou fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Tramping Charge
entries: If Shathou moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, Shathou can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: Shathou's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Shathou makes one attack with its gore and one with its stomp.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 4d8 + 6}) piercing damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Healing Touch (3/Day)
entries: Shathou touches another creature. The target magically regains 24 ({@dice 4d8 + 8}) hit points and is freed from any curse, disease, poison, blindness, or deafness.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: Shathou uses one of the following breath weapons.

items.name: Radiant Blast
items.entry: Shathou fires a beam of radiant energy in a line that is 100 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Flaring Stance
items.entry: Shathou emits a flash of dazzling light from its hrons in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded}. Undead within the area of effect must also make a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw or be turned for 1 minute. Undead of CR 4 or lower who fail the saving throw are instantly destroyed.

action.name: Radiant Strike (1/Day)
entries: Shathou chooses a point on the ground it can see within 60 feet of it. A 30-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder of bright light appears there until the start of Shathou's next turn. Each creature in the cylinder when it appears or that ends its turn there must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw, taking 72 ({@damage 12d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Structures and unattended objects in the cylinder are immediately disintegrated.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The shriekbat can't use its {@sense blindsight} while {@condition deafened}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shriekbat makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its talons.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the shriekbat can't use its talons on another target.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: The shriekbat emits a powerful burst of sound in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 12d6}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target is also {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A {@condition stunned} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
This midnight-blue bat has a cavern-filling wingspan. The air near its mouth, large enough to carry a horse, visibly vibrates with sound pulses.

Shriekbats thrive in the cavernous spaces of the Underworld where they face little competition from dragons, rocs, and other large flying creatures, as they would aboveground. Despite their enormousness, the bats deftly maneuver among the stalactites and stalagmites crowding underground caverns. When they attack prey, or in the very rare cases where they must escape predators, they emit a terrible shriek that overwhelms their foes and allows them to easily grab prey or escape. Shriekbat echolocation uses subsonic frequencies, allowing the bats to fly in relative silence.

entries.name: Kobold Companions
entries: Kobold bat keepers know the secret to raising young shriekbats. The bat keepers often risk their lives to procure young, using the bats for protection and as companions. A bat keeper returns its shriekbat to the wild before the bat reaches adulthood, when it would become too large for the cramped kobold tunnels. A bat keeper tracks the shriekbats it releases, and often returns to visit its former companions. Shriekbats prove surprisingly keen at remembering former kobold handlers (whether such handlers treated them well or poorly), and they often allow fondly remembered handlers to take a single pup from their litters, ensuring the pup survives to adulthood and renewing the cycle.

entries.name: Long-Lived Omnivores
entries: Shriekbats live for nearly 50 years. They are social and promiscuous creatures that live in small groups in large caverns. They are omnivorous but prefer fresh meat to other food with lizards taking up the majority of their diet. Shriekbats can survive on rotten flesh, which allows them to eat ghouls and other undead populating the Underworld, but they find it less palatable. In overcrowded situations where multiple groups of shriekbats roost in the same cavern, a group of shriekbats might break away to find another hunting location if food becomes scarce.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The shrieker's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The shrieker can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The shrieker can mimic any sounds it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom (Insight) check.

trait.name: Passing Bite
entries: If the shrieker moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target, it has advantage on its next attack roll against that target.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The shrieker has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shrieker makes two attacks; one with its beak and one with its claw.

action.name: Serrated Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) slashing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage at the beginning of its next turn.

action.name: Kicking Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Infrasound (1/Short Rest)
entries: The shrieker emits a low humming sound, causing its prey to hallucinate vividly. Any creature within 30 feet of the shrieker must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or begin seeing perfect illusionary duplicates of the shrieker. The shrieker can control each duplicate individually although the illusionary duplicates can deal no damage nor can be damaged. Any afflicted creatures can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature succeeds on its saving throw, it is immune to the shrieker's infrasound for 24 hours.

{@italic In the dense forests of the world, many dangerous creatures reside within. Bears, mammoths, tigers, wolves, the forest is a terrifying place that invokes a primal sense of fear so great that only the bravest few dare to venture inside. Shriekers utilizes this crippling fear to their advantage, preying on the frightened and isolated, feeding into their paranoia before finally striking while the creature is paralyzed with terror. }

{@bold Aberrant Predators.} While shriekers appear to be avian in appearance, these creatures have an alien anatomy that is more similar to an arthropod than any vertebrate. They rely on what can only be considered biological machinery to function, as their physiology is extremely complex and borderline unnatural. As a result, these creatures are capable of abilities that appear to be supernatural. Shriekers have two specialized chitinous organs extending from their backs that can emit a cloud of a nontoxic bleaching compound that absorbs direct sunlight, blackening the area around it. This compound spreads through the air like ink in water, blotting out any light in the area. Shriekers use this compound to trap terrified prey in a cloud of darkness, toying with them before ultimately delivering the killing blow with their unusually shaped beaks. These beaks are quite peculiar, consisting of a powerful, armored upper jaw and a much narrower lower jaw that splits into two serrated mandibles when opened fully. It is unknown what the purpose of this adaptation is.

{@bold Forest Dwellers.} Shriekers reside in dense temperate rainforests, claiming massive territories of thick forestland. They prefer areas where the canopy blots out sunlight, darkening the forest floor in a permanent shade of gray. They specialize in preying on skittish creatures, tormenting prey with their multiple adaptations before pouncing on them when they are at their most vulnerable. They prefer to ambush their prey, as they are quite cowardly in a one-on-one fight. By no means does this make them incapable of defending themselves, however, as they are capable of quickly turning the tables on would-be predators when cornered, utilizing their darkening compound to devastating effect. Shriekers are primarily solitary, but occasionally hunt in groups of two or three, although these hunting groups are extremely uncooperative and often form temporarily in order to take down larger prey.

{@bold Sound-Oriented.} Shriekers are known for their incredible mastery of sound, utilizing it for a number of various uses. Shriekers can map the surrounding environment entirely through echolocation, achieving this by opening a flap on the base of their skull, which contains an inner organ that acts similarly to an extremely sensitive eardrum. This enables them to pick up the slightest soundwaves with ease, allowing them to pinpoint the exact location of any sound in the surrounding area. They can produce powerful bursts of ear-piercing noise, shrieking loud enough to deal damage to their surroundings. Perhaps most peculiar, however, is their extended use of infrasound. By emitting inaudibly low frequencies, they can cause extreme paranoia and panic in most organisms, allowing them to trigger an ambush easily. Additionally, they can cause blindness in some creatures and deafen others simply by tampering with chemicals in the victim’s brain. They often provoke hallucinations in their prey, causing affected creatures to see illusionary duplicates of the shrieker that allow it to guide and herd the prey deeper into its hunting grounds.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The silverback makes two fist attacks.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, the silverback can choose to grapple it (escape {@dc 14}).

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 25/50 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Charging Bluff
entries: The silverback moves at least 15 feet in a straight line and then roars and beats its chest. Each creature of the silverback's choice within 20 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of the silverback until the end of its next turn.

Adult male gorillas are referred to as silverbacks for the silvery gray patches of fur extending onto their hulking backs. Silverbacks are powerful animals, with a stocky build, broad chest, and long, extremely muscular arms. Silverbacks are often the leaders of their troops, leading them with unparalleled strength and unwavering ferocity. Despite their strength, silverbacks are primarily docile and gentle creatures.

trait.name: Bad Flier
entries: The storm chicken falls at the end of its turn if it's airborne and the only thing holding it aloft is its flying speed.

trait.name: Call of the Storm
entries: The storm chicken can cast {@spell control weather} at will, requiring no material components and requiring only one action to cast, in which the storm chicken crows into the ether above, pleading for the dark gods to answer its malevolent cry.

action.name: Peck
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft, one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d1 + 2}) piercing damage.

{@italic Villagers scramble about a lively town square, busily going about their daily lives. They were grateful for such a beautiful day, as the past week had been dreary and gray. Disgusted by the joy of it all, an average-looking rooster perches upon a fencepost, observing the people as they enjoyed the simplicity of life. The bird crowed loudly, emitting a hoarse, cackling call. The townsfolk, too preoccupied with their own existences, paid the chicken no mind. Laughing to itself, the malevolent little rooster knew that in just a few minutes, the clear blue sky would be crowded with puffy gray clouds, threatening to fill the surrounding area with a light drizzle. This day would be regarded as a minor annoyance by many.}

Alright, first of all, screw the formalities. I made this thing late at night because I was bored and wanted to make a powerful little chicken monster. So basically, I made this malevolent little bastard. He looks like a regular rooster, but he actually is a malicious little monstrosity thing that can control the very weather with his crow, which is hoarse as {@italic fuck}. So he goes around and makes beautiful days shitty so that he can dance atop the sorrows of people. Busy day? Rain. Wedding? Rain. Party? Rain. This deep fried little shit is the lord of minor inconveniences. Also, he can control the literal fucking weather, so don’t piss him off. He will tornado your house.

trait.name: Iron Scent
entries: The boar can pinpoint, by scent, the location of ferrous metal within 60 feet of it.

trait.name: Lightning Hide
entries: A creature that touches the boar or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) lightning damage.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the boar takes 15 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hp, it is reduced to 1 hp instead.

trait.name: Thunder Charge
entries: If the boar moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 11 ({@damage 2d10}) thunder damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) lightning damage. In addition, nonmagical metal armor worn by the target is partly devoured by the boar and takes a permanent and cumulative 2 penalty to the AC it offers. The armor is destroyed if the penalty reduces its AC to 10.

action.name: Lightning Run {@recharge 6}
entries: The boar becomes a bolt of living lightning and moves up to its speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks}. It can move through creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage and is pushed to the closest unoccupied space if it ends its turn inside an object. Each creature in the boar's path must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Thunder Leap {@recharge 6}
entries: The boar moves up to 20 feet, jumping over obstacles in its way. Difficult terrain doesn't cost it extra movement when it leaps. Each creature within 10 feet of the boar when it leaps and each creature within 10 feet of where it lands must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 16 ({@damage 3d10}) thunder damage and is pushed up to 10 feet away from the boar. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't pushed.
A massive, green-scaled boar snorts angrily as tiny bolts of blue lightning ripple over its body.

entries.name: Accidental Arcane Creations
entries: An {@creature evoker|vgm} who raised hogs to fund their wild experiments, accidentally blew up their tower years ago. The explosion created a horrific storm that raged for days in the region, causing the locals to take shelter. When the storm dissipated, the wizard and their tower were gone, but the hogs had been transformed into scaled beasts that harnessed the power of lightning and thunder.

entries.name: Storm's Fury
entries: Stormboars embody the fury of the storm. Just as stubborn and ferocious as their more mundane cousins, stormboars let no obstacle get in their way while they look for food or protect their offspring. Seasoned hunters know to drop an offering of metal behind as they leave the area to ensure the boar is too distracted to follow them.

entries.name: Metal Devourers
entries: Stormboars crave metal. Prospectors track the boars to find areas rich with precious minerals and ore, and treasure hunters use the creatures to sniff out hidden vaults of wealth. Anyone relying on a stormboar must be careful, however. The boars see any creature wearing or carrying metal as the deliverer of an easy meal. The aggressive creatures won't stop attacking until they've consumed every bit of metal an unfortunate traveler is carrying. Starving stormboars have been known to venture into civilized areas for a meal.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The ithjar has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Slippery Serpent
entries: The ithjar has advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to escape a grapple or saving throws to avoid being {@condition paralyzed} or {@condition restrained}.

trait.name: Churn Lightning
entries: When the stormborne ithjar moves, creatures within 5 feet of it take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The stormborne ithjar doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The stormborne ithjar attacks once with its bite and once with its constrict.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) slashing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) lightning damage.

action.name: Constrict
entries: {@i Melee Weapon Attack:} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Large or smaller creature. {@i Hit:} 17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) slashing damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}) if the ithjar isn't already constricting a creature, and the target is {@condition restrained} until this grapple ends. If it has a target {@condition grappled}, the ithjar can't use its constrict against another creature

action.name: Storm Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The stormborne exhales a line of lightning that is 100 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 52 ({@damage 8d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

reaction.name: Writhing Escape
entries: When {@condition grappled}, the ithjar can attempt to escape.
{@i “It takes mere moments for an ithjar to transform from a kite-like swirl of gray and red in the distance to a menace of snapping teeth.”}

{@b Airborne Ophidian.} An ithjar is a monstrous, snake-like flying predator. It writhes through the clouds seeking prey with vision that rivals that of a raptor. Once an ithjar locates a potential meal, the ithjar flies in a strange, swirling fashion, reminiscent of a long-tailed kite. As the ithjar closes in, that curious flying pattern becomes a whirlwind of violence and death. Rows of slashing teeth line the crocodilian mouth of an ithjar. These fangs flay flesh from bone and can penetrate strong armor.

{@b Writhing Foe.} Opposite the ithjar’s mouth is a tail studded with spiked fins. The ithjar uses this tail to lash or ensnare prey. An ithjar’s lithe form and chaotic movement allows it to evade and confuse foes. But that’s not the only danger. The monster is hard to catch, escaping from a hold almost as quickly as a foe can wrestle it. An ithjar can quickly turn the tables on an enemy intent on capturing it. Its constricting coils can be as deadly as its bite.

{@b Stormborne Scourge.} Ithjars have been seen hunting alone, in small groups, and in packs. Such packs have been described as a glistening hurricane of scales, teeth, and blood. But far worse than the common ithjar is the stormborne ithjar. Those monsters add to their ferocity with the elemental powers of a storm.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The styxosaurus can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The styxosaurus deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) piercing damage. If the target is Huge or smaller, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}) and {@condition restrained}. The styxosaurus has advantage on any bite attack against a creature it is grappling.

action.name: Wave {@recharge 5}
entries: The styxosaurus creates a wave of water that crashes forward in a line that is 40 feet long and 20 feet wide, originating from any point within a large body of water that the styxosaurus is in. Each creature in the area when the wave crashes down must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.
Wave, bite, sink, and chew... the Styxosaur ate all me crew.

Ancient, gargantuan, and the last of its kind, the styxosaurus stalks the various lakes and pools of Argoloth. Though hard to miss when walloping its way between lakes, this beast is a stealthy predator that strikes from the water. Tales have spread far and wide of the 'Beast of Lo'kness,' drawing big game hunters from across the continent. None have, as yet, been successful.

{@bold Lakeside Ambusher.} The lakes of Argoloth are not big enough to keep to keep this beast fed; it must also hunt the larger beasts who satiate their thirst at the lake's edge. It waits, motionless, on the lake's bed, feeling for vibrations on the shoreline. With a whip of its tail, it generates a huge wave which can floor even the might tyrannosaurus, before snatching the prone creature in its ferocious maw and dragging it deep into the depths to be devoured.

trait.name: Hypnotic Plumage
entries: When a creature that can see the sunset raptor's tail starts its turn within 100 feet of the raptor, the raptor can force it to make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw if the raptor isn't {@condition incapacitated} and can see the creature. On a failure, a creature becomes {@condition charmed} until the start of its next turn. While {@condition charmed}, the creature is {@condition incapacitated} as it suffers from surreal hallucinations and must move up to its speed closer to the raptor that {@condition charmed} it. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but before moving into damaging terrain, such as lava or a pit, and whenever it takes damage from a source other than the sunset raptor, a target can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. Other sunset raptors are immune to this effect.

Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the sunset raptor until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the sunset raptor in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The sunset raptor has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the raptor's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the sunset raptor moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the sunset raptor can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The sunset raptor has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Hooked Claws
entries: A creature {@condition grappled} by the sunset raptor at the beginning of its turn takes 11 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The sunset raptor can mimic simple sounds it has heard, such as a person whispering, a baby crying, or an animal chittering. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check contesting the sunset raptor's Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check.

trait.name: Glide
entries: The primary feathers of the sunset raptor allow it to glide short distances. When the sunset raptor falls and is not {@condition incapacitated}, the sunset raptor can subtract up to 100 feet from its fall when calculating fall damage and can move horizontally 2 feet for every 1 foot it falls.
In addition, the sunset raptor can expend all of its movement on a single turn to leap up to 150 feet vertically or horizontally.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sunset raptor makes one attack with its bite and two with its claws. If the sunset raptor hits a single target with two claw attacks, the creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.
The captain just stared with wet eyes and a dazed smile, whispering something I couldn't hear. He just stared while they tore him apart. I just stared while they tore him apart.
entries.by: The lone survivor of a sunset raptor attack

entries: {@b Beautiful Threat.} A sunset raptor can be identified by its vibrant plumage, crested head, and large peacock-like tail of gorgeous feathers. Its tail feathers are reflective and mesmerizing, triggering surreal hallucinations of a spectator's dreams, desires, and nightmares. Entirely unique, no sunset raptor’s plumage pattern or color is the same, making for a variety of elegant and dazzling plumages.

{@b Deadly Oddities.} Vicious and exotic, sunset raptors are highly prized among eccentric collectors. They can often be found guarding the lairs of mad wizards or stalking the gardens of giants. Jewelers, alchemists, and fortune tellers covet sunset raptor feathers for their bright color and use in spiritual rituals. However, sunset raptors are not easily caught or tamed, and many hunters and handlers have been devoured for not taking the proper precautions against these vibrant killers.

{@b Social Predators.} Sunset raptors have developed remarkably efficient pack tactics. They communicate using shrill, piercing calls, gliding at high speeds in and out of the tandem of battle. Often, the fastest raptors glide ahead of the pack, cutting off potential prey. Once their prey is cornered, the raptors close in, forming a ring and forcing their prey to gaze upon their deadly, hypnotic plumages.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: In the first round of combat, the tembril has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

trait.name: Distant Leap
entries: The tembril can jump horizontally up to 20 feet and vertically up to 10 feet, with or without a running start.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the tembril is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the tembril instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tembril makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws. If both claw attacks hit the same target, that target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) and {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage. If the tembril scores a critical hit against a Medium or smaller target and the damage reduces the target to below half its hit point maximum, the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw or be instantly killed as its head is removed. A creature is immune to this effect if it is immune to piercing damage or doesn't have or need a head.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Maddening Chitter {@recharge 6}
entries: The tembril chitters maddeningly in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage and is {@condition incapacitated} and {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. If a creature fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it also suffers {@table short-term madness}. An {@condition incapacitated} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending both conditions on itself on a success.

bonus.name: Nimble
entries: The tembril can take the {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

Standing on its back legs and holding a decapitated human head in its hands, this nightmarish creature resembles a gigantic squirrel with saber-like teeth, soulless black eyes, and hard, scaly skin. It chitters softly and eerily.

entries.name: Forest Terrors
entries: In the dark and foreboding forests of the north, tales are spun of terrible ogres, hags, evil wolves, and great arctic serpents, but humans and ogres alike fear the tembril, a savage beast that feeds specifically on the eyes, tongues, and brains of humanoids. Resembling a squirrel the size of a bear, but with brown scales and immense claws and fangs, the tembril hunts sapient fey, humanoids, and giants exclusively, using its claws to eviscerate its opponent as its teeth punctures their skulls.

entries.name: Head Collectors
entries: The victim of a tembril attack is almost always found without its head, for the creature collects the severed cranium to devour the contents either immediately or at a later time. Tembrils store the heads in the long winter months, hiding them within the hollows of great trees or in other suitable locations and covering them in ice so they don't decompose. The decapitated bodies left behind make a meal for many forest-dwelling scavengers, and {@creature crow|wdmm|crows}, {@creature worg|mm|worgs}, and even {@creature ghoul|mm|ghouls} have been known to follow in a tembril's wake, looking for a fresh feast.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The tether cricket can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Sense
entries: While in contact with a web, the tether cricket knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The tether cricket ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The tether cricket's long jump is up to 30 feet and its high jump is up to 15 feet, with or without a running start.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tether cricket attacks twice with its claws and once with its entangle.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Entangle
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h} The target is {@condition restrained} by powerful webbing. As an action, the {@condition restrained} target can make a {@dc 18} Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 18; hit points 30; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

action.name: Webbing {@recharge 5}
entries: The tether cricket spins a large web in a space within 10 feet of it. This webbing works like the {@spell web|PHB} spell, but the save DC is 17 and the web is not magical. The web lasts until destroyed.

action.name: Create Marionette
entries: One creature the tether cricket can see within 60 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or become entangled by a controlling link. This link appears as a barely perceptible web between the tether cricket and the target. A linked creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the link on a success. A linked creature that is immune to being {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained} immediately succeeds on the saving throw.

While a target is linked, the tether cricket can control the target at the start of the target's turn. The tether cricket can make the target move, manipulate objects, attack, or take other purely physical actions. The tether cricket can't make the target cast spells or speak. While controlled, the target moves awkwardly and has disadvantage on all ability checks and saving throws using Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution. If the target receives a suicidal command from the tether cricket, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

The tether cricket can have up to three targets linked at a time. If it links another, the effect on the previous target ends. If a creature dies while linked to the tether cricket, the effect immediately ends for that creature.

bonus.name: Tether Swing
entries: The tether cricket fires a thread of webbing which allows it to swing through the landscape. Until the end of its next turn, the tether cricket gains a flying speed of 80 feet. When it stops swinging, the tether cricket falls if it is still aloft, unless it can stop the fall. The tether cricket must have ample space and tall structures to swing from such as tall buildings or trees.

{@i A thread of webbing, tough as steel, quickly adheres to the dry canyon wall, fired with extreme speed. On its opposite end, a large, brown insect the size of a horse swings gracefully through the air, firing off three other webs in quick succession.}
Surpassing the agility of a trained acrobat, the tether cricket hunts from the air, swinging from surface to surface with its ability to fire a sticky webbing at high speeds.

{@b Complicated Classification.} The tether cricket is an odd creature to classify, as it only slightly resembles a cricket. The tether cricket possesses eight limbs like an arachnid, though it resembles a praying mantis more than any spider or scorpion. Tether crickets are oftentimes confused for insectoid centaurs, which can prove to be dangerous to the viewer.

{@b Unconventionally Airborne.} Tether crickets do not possess wings and are actually extremely heavy for their size, though they manage to hunt in the air anyway. The tether cricket does this by producing an extremely durable and adhesive webbing that it fires from it can eject from its two pairs of forelimbs. These threads of webbing attach to anything they touch, effectively acting as tethers between the cricket and any solid surface it attaches to. From there, the cricket uses its incredible agility to flip and swing through the air at high speeds, creating new tethers to support its “flight.”

{@b Puppeteers.} Tether crickets are known to inhabit large, enclosed areas such as canyons and dense jungles to better use their tethering abilities. Tether crickets also utilize these areas to better make use of another of its talents. When tether crickets make a lair, they fill a large, open space with hundreds of tiny, nearly invisible lines of webbing. When a creature touches or otherwise interacts with the webbing, all of the threads enclose the creature at once, binding them in place. Tether crickets can manipulate each strand of webbing with extreme precision, forcing prey to move to the cricket’s desires.

monster.name: The Gargoyle

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the Gargoyle fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Overwhelming Strength
entries: The Gargoyle can lift up to 600,000 pounds, or 300 tons.

trait.name: Ember Wreath (1/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the Gargoyle wreathes its body in searing red and orange embers. The embers last for 1 minute or until the Gargoyle uses its breath weapon. While the embers are active, the Gargoyle's weapon attacks deal an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage on a hit. A creature that enters or starts its turn in a space within 30 feet of the Gargoyle while its Ember Wreath is active must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If a creature fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion} as the water is sapped from its body by the unrelenting heat.

trait.name: Opportunistic
entries: The Gargoyle is intelligent enough to utilize its environment in combat. The Gargoyle can pick up any object that it could reasonably use and wield, gaining a new melee weapon attack. The new improvised weapon attack uses the Gargoyle's Strength modifier for attack rolls, has a reach of 20 feet, and deals 33 ({@damage 4d12 + 7}) bludgeoning, slashing, or piercing damage depending on the nature of the weapon. The improvised weapon deals double damage to unattended objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Gargoyle makes a bite attack and two fist attacks. If the Gargoyle is wielding an improvised weapon, it can attack with it twice.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Huge or smaller, the Gargoyle can choose to grapple it (escape {@dc 19}). While {@condition grappled}, the target is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Comet
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 50/100 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Immolating Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The Gargoyle exhales intense flame in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 63 ({@damage 18d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendaryHeader: The Gargoyle can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The Gargoyle regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The Gargoyle makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Grab
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}) and {@condition restrained}.

legendary.name: Throw
entries: The Gargoyle throws one creature it has {@condition grappled}. The creature is thrown a distance of {@dice 2d6} times 10 feet in the direction the ape chooses, and takes 20 ({@damage 2d12 + 7}) bludgeoning damage (plus falling damage if they are thrown into a chasm or off a cliff). The ape can throw a creature up to Large size. Small creatures are thrown twice as far, but the damage is the same.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Gargoyle beats its wings. Each creature within 15 ft. of the ape must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The Gargoyle can then fly up to half its flying speed.

{@italic As the surrounding blizzard persisted mercilessly, two young goliaths trekked through the rock and snow. As stubborn as they were, they were unwilling to admit that they were lost, miles away from their mountainous village. As the pair stopped for a brief rest, a deep, grumbling roar pierced the shrieking winds. To their horror, the silhouette of an ogre loomed just meters away from them, wielding a colossal tree trunk. Exhausted and sore, the two goliaths gripped their weapons tightly, readying themselves for their final battle. As the ogre charged, the two goliaths let out a triumphant war cry which, to their surprise, was overtaken by an echoing draconic roar that carried for miles. From behind, the two goliaths felt an intense heat grace their backs, melting the frost and snow. They watched as a massive, winged figure leapt high above their heads before crashing atop the bewildered ogre. The ape-like creature subjected the troll-kin to a flurry of devastating blows, shattering its bones like paper. With a ferocious, bellowing roar, the ogre was lifted high above the beast’s head and effortlessly thrown to the jagged rocks below. Both impressed and terrified, the two goliaths looked on in awe as the creature turned to them and bowed its head before unfurling its massive wings and taking flight, vanishing from sight in a swarm of embers.}
A legendary creature of both draconic and simian descent, the Gargoyle is a savior to those lost in the desolate, frozen mountains that it calls home.

{@bold Mysterious Origins.} The circumstances in which the Gargoyle was born is considered a mystery by all, as its unique combination of both draconic and hominid traits is, as far as most are concerned, completely irreproducible. It is heavily speculated that the creature is a half-dragon of sorts, but the manner in which it was conceived is unknown. Nonetheless, the Gargoyle combines the traits of a silverback gorilla and a red dragon to devastating effect. Covered in both the muscular, impenetrable hide of a dragon and the shaggy, warming fur of an ape, the Gargoyle is, for an unknown reason, mostly gray, resembling a stone statue. The only touch of color present on the massive creature is its massive, leathery wings, in which its membrane is a darkened crimson. The Gargoyle earned its name due to these wings, its bestial humanoid physique, the concrete-like appearance of its hide, and its long, dragon-like tail that ends in a devilish point.

{@bold Chimeric Personality.} Similarly to its appearance, the Gargoyle’s personality is tainted by draconic habit. The beast shares a fondness of mountains with its reptilian parent, preferring to lair at high altitudes. It shares a dragon’s greed, collecting trinkets and other items that it considers to be valuable, which are often playthings. It collects wagon wheels, tree trunks, boulders, and even other animals. It’s extremely fond of large grazing animals such as yaks and elk. The Gargoyle is omnivorous, although it prefers to live a more herbivorous lifestyle, grazing with its “troop” and protecting them ferociously. While normally docile and playful, if the Gargoyle encounters anything it perceives as a threat to itself or its troop, it will attack with unexpected levels of primal aggression, combining the blazing fury of a red dragon and the frightening strength of a gorilla. Its mastery of flame surpasses its parent’s, allowing it to wreathe itself in scorching embers.

monster.name: The Gitrog Monster
languages: understands all languages but can't speak

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The Gitrog can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Poisonous Secretion
entries: A creature that touches the Gitrog must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw at the end of its turn or become {@condition poisoned} for the next 12 hours. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a creature also suffers disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws. The {@condition poisoned} creature or a creature within 5 feet of it can use an action to make a {@dc 18} Wisdom (Medicine) check to end the effect.

trait.name: Hypnotic Gaze
entries: When a creature starts its turn within 120 feet of the Gitrog and is able to see the Gitrog's eyes, the Gitrog can magically force it to succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} by the toad until the Gitrog dies or until it is on a different plane of existence from the target. Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the Gitrog until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the Gitrog in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

A {@condition charmed} creature is under the Gitrog's control. The Gitrog and the target can communicate telepathically with each other over any distance. Whenever the {@condition charmed} target takes damage or when it starts its turn at least 1 mile away from the Gitrog, the target can repeat the saving throw. On a success, the effect ends. The save can be made no more than once every 24 hours. A target that successfully saves is immune to the Gitrog's Hypnotic Gaze for the next hour.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Gitrog uses its Dominating Croak. It then makes one bite attack and one claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the Gitrog. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the Gitrog, and it takes 16 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the Gitrog's turns.

If the Gitrog takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the Gitrog must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the Gitrog. If the Gitrog dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d4 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Dominating Croak
entries: A creature within 120 feet of the Gitrog that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage and immediately turn to look at the Gitrog. Alternatively, the Gitrog can choose any number of creatures within 20 feet of it that can hear it. Each creature must suceed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw, immediately turning to look at the Gitrog on a failure.

reaction.name: Reconstitute
entries: If the Gitrog is suffering from one or more effects that require it to make a saving throw to end, it may immediately make a save against each effect. A successful save for any of the throws will end the effect immediately. The only saving throws that this reaction can be used for are saves that are made at the end/start of the Gitrog's next turn or using its action. It can use this reaction while {@condition incapacitated}.

reaction.name: Redirect Attack
entries: When a creature the Gitrog can see targets it with an attack, the Gitrog can choose another creature {@condition charmed} by it within 5 feet of it. The two swap places, and the chosen creature becomes the target instead.

The Gitrog Monster is a figure of legend, feared by those living in certain remote villages. The tales surrounding this creature are often vague and contradictory, but they all describe a monstrous lake-dwelling amphibian that feeds on villagers and their livestock. The presence of the Gitrog Monster in or near a village spells doom for its helpless inhabitants.

{@b Unknown Number and Orgin.} While the legends refer to a single creature known as the Gitrog Monster, how many of these abominations actually exist is unknown. It may be a single legendary creature or a rare breed of beasts that rarely make their presence overtly known. The Gitrog’s origin is equally ambiguous. Because of the striking similarities between their powers and those of the hypnotoad, those who have studied the Gitrog extensively believe that it may have once been a giant hypnotoad. How it would have gained this level of power and status is unknown. Perhaps a particularly ancient hypnotoad devoured enough of its followers to grow into an even greater monster. Alternatively, a hypnotoad may have been warped by strange, eldritch powers from another world. Whatever the case, the Gitrog’s inscrutable mind betrays no secrets of its past nor plans for its future.

{@b Cult Followings.} The Gitrog Monster possesses most of the abilities of a giant hypnotoad, albeit at a much higher level of power. However, the ways in which the Gitrog utilizes its powers differ from its lesser cousins. Whereas hypnotoads often make themselves publicly known as they take on prominent local positions within a community, the Gitrog remains hidden away from public view. Though it usually stays out of sight, the weight of the Gitrog’s presence is felt throughout the entire community. Rather than inject itself into petty social games, the Gitrog uses its influence to create dark cults with itself at the center. These cults are formed from inhabitants from any nearby village, and the cult’s members may include those serving purely out of fear or dark pragmatism and desire for power. Still, other members are true believers in the Gitrog’s greatness, their psyche shattered, leaving them only with the desire to do whatever is necessary to serve their horrific master’s whims.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The kraken's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 18}). It can innately cast the following spells:

trait.name: Jet
entries: While underwater, the kraken can take the dash action to jet backward at a speed of 140 feet. It must move in a straight line while using this ability.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The kraken can breathe air and water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kraken makes eight tentacle attacks and one mandibles attack. It can substitute two tentacles attacks for one constrict attack if it has a creature {@condition grappled} at the start of its turn, but it never constricts more than once per turn.

action.name: Mangling Mandibles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 3d8 + 9}) slashing damage. This attack scores a critical hit on a target that is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 35 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 1d6 + 9}) piercing damage. If two tentacle attacks hit the same target in one turn, the target is also {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}).

action.name: Constrict
entries: The constricted creature takes 29 ({@damage 3d12 + 9}) bludgeoning damage and is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}) and {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Storm Cloud {@recharge 5}
entries: The kraken emits dark, rolling clouds that flash with lightning in a 30-foot cloud as a bonus action. The cloud affects vision as the darkness spell, and any creature that starts its turn inside the cloud takes 11 ({@damage 3d6}) lightning damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw. The kraken's {@sense darkvision} is not impaired by this cloud. The cloud persists for 1 minute, then disperses.

action.name: Vomit Forth the Deeps (1/Day)
entries: The kraken sprays electrified bile from its maw over a 30-foot cone. This shocking slurry causes 36 ({@damage 8d8}) lightning damage and targets must make a successful {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of their next turn.

action.name: Lightning Strike {@recharge}
entries: The kraken conjures a magical lightning bolt at a point it can see within 500 feet of it. Each creature within 10 feet of that point must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 54 ({@damage 10d8}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Tentacle
entries: The kraken makes two tentacles attack.

legendary.name: Hammer Arm (Uses 2 Actions)
entries: The kraken slams one of its bludgeoning arms down at a point it can see within 60 feet of it. Each creature within 10 feet of that point must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 ({@dice 8d6}) bludgeoning and lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The kraken moves up to half its speed.

As our vessel crashed through yet another destructive wave, a number of the men started screaming and pointing at something in the sky. Looking up at it, I- Gods alive… Long, dark tentacles dangled from the sky as something descended from the rolling storm above. Lightning flashed, and the silhouette of a squid-like monster was illuminated by the flaring light. Its tendrils coiled around various members of the crew as an electric roar echoed louder than thunder. Hemmins, Jackson, Cathaway… it ate them. It ate them all.

Louder than thunder and more potent than lightning, the Kraken is a monstrous colossal squid that developed a destructive bond with the Elemental Plane of Air, harnessing the soul of the storm to wreak havoc on unsuspecting ships. Like its rival and nemesis, the White Whale, the Kraken exclusively preys on the flesh of humanoids, preferring the taste of sentient flesh and blood to anything else. On clear, sunny days, the Kraken drifts underneath the waves, submerged, scanning the horizon for evidence of humanoid presence. When lighting crackles through the air and the clouds are thick and dark, the Kraken rises up, hiding in the clouds and pulling sailors, pirates, and even entire ships into the sky to be crushed and devoured.

monster.name: The Sharptooth

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Sharptooth's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 20}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Dread Reaper
entries: The Sharptooth scores a critical hit on any creature that is {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The Sharptooth's long jump is up to 50 feet and its high jump is up to 30 feet, with or without a running start.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The Sharptooth deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the Sharptooth moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, the target must succeed on a {@dc 23} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the Sharptooth can make a bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the Sharptooth fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Mega Predator
entries: The Sharptooth's weapon attacks are magical. In addition, the Sharptooth's attack rolls have advantage if its target is Large or smaller.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The Sharptooth has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Sharptooth makes three attacks: two with its bite and one with its stomp or tail. It can use its Swallow in place of its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}42 ({@damage 5d12 + 10}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 23}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and The Sharptooth can't bite another target or use its Prehistoric Scream.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The Sharptooth makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, that creature takes the bite's damage and is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside Gishath, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of The Sharptooth's turns.

If The Sharptooth takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of it. If The Sharptooth dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d4 + 10}) slashing damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 23} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 23} Dexterity saving throw or be thrown up to 15 feet away from The Sharptooth and be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Prehistoric Scream {@recharge 5}
entries: The Sharptooth emits a petrifying roar in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area that can hear the Sharptooth must make a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, a creature is {@condition frightened} and {@condition incapacitated} for 1 minute as the terror of extinction lays waste to its mind. On a success, a creature suffers no ill effects. An {@condition incapacitated} or {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending both effects on itself on a success.

legendaryHeader: The Sharptooth can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The Sharptooth regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Sharptooth makes one stomp or tail attack.

legendary.name: Rush
entries: The Sharptooth moves up to its speed.

legendary.name: Tail Spin (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Sharptooth spins in a wide circle, swinging its tail at any creatures within range. The Sharptooth makes a tail attack against each creature within 20 feet of it.

A manifestation of predatory malice in the form of nature's ultimate tyrant king, the Sharptooth dwarfs the largest of the behemoths, stomping, slashing, and tearing its way through the prehistoric jungles of Chult. It feeds on fear, preferring to fill its prey with the blind panic of complete extinctual annihilation whenever it roars, sending them into a thoughtless scramble and reducing them to nothing more than simple, mindless prey.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The whale's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution. It can innately cast the following spells (spell save {@dc 19}), requiring no material components:
will: {@spell create or destroy water} (90 gallons; rains approximately 5,335,923,600 gallons)

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the whale hits with it (included in the attack).

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The whale can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The whale can hold its breath for 90 minutes.

trait.name: Flooded
entries: Any space that has been flooded by one of the whale's actions is filled with two to three feet of water, and it is difficult terrain for any creature without an innate or magical swimming speed. The flooded areas remain flooded for 24 hours, until the whale absorbs the water, or until it is turned to steam.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The whale has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the whale fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Cackling
entries: The skeleton of Captain Ahab cackles madly, disorienting each creature that can hear him and isn’t {@condition incapacitated}. Each creature that starts its turn within 20 feet of the whale and can hear the cackling must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature can't take reactions until the start of its next turn and begins to hallucinate, becoming afflicted with a short-term madness effect (determined randomly or by the DM). The effect lasts 10 minutes and the target can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The whale makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}42 ({@damage 4d12 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the whale. A swallowed creature has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the whale, and it takes 24 ({@damage 8d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the whale's turns. If the whale takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the whale must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the whale. If the whale dies, a swallowed creature can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage, or 44 ({@damage 8d6 + 16}) bludgeoning damage if the target is an object.

action.name: Tidal Wave
entries: The whale conjures up a wave of water that crashes down on an area in front of it. The area can be up to 30 feet long, up to 10 feet wide, and up to 10 feet tall. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone} on a failed save, or half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone} on a successful one. The water then spreads out 15 feet across the ground in all directions, flooding the area.

action.name: Maelstrom
entries: The water in a 30-foot radius around the whale is pulled towards it and absorbed into its body, increasing its AC by 2 until the end of its next turn. Each creature in flooded terrain must make a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and be pulled 10 feet toward the whale on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one and is not pulled.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The whale uses a tail attack.

legendary.name: Charge (Uses 2 Actions)
entries: The whale moves up to its speed in a straight line without provoking opportunity attacks. Any creature or object caught in its path must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save and being pushed 10 feet away from the whale. On a successful save, the target is not affected by this attack.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The whale makes a perception check.

In most sea-faring cultures, tales about epic battles between brave sailors and massive leviathans are incorporated so deeply within their society that, as time goes on, some believe the legends of heroism and adventure to be accurate recounts of the sea, and thus embark on epic quests to search for and slay dangerous nautical fiends. In most cases, these stories truly are just myth, but in one of the most famous tales of all, the beast recounted was a true demon. Moby Dick, the White Whale, is an ancient predator that stalks the seas in search of whaling ships to destroy so that it may devour the blood of man to feed its insatiable appetite for flesh. Resembling a massive sperm whale with an enormous, toothed maw, the White Whale commands the sea to its whim, and is capable of conjuring colossal waves at will. Occasionally, it will create massive tsunamis in order to sweep inland, carrying warm flesh out to sea where it can be easily devoured. Several harpoons are embedded within its thick hide, and a skeleton ensnared to its back cackles madly.

monster.name: The Yeti

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The Yeti can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The Yeti's long jump is up to 30 feet and its high jump is up to 15 feet, with or without a running start. In addition, the Yeti does not provoke attacks of opportunity while moving with a jump.

trait.name: Conjure Ice Sword
entries: After the Yeti uses its frigid blast, it can create a blade made of ice on one or both of its claws as a bonus action. An ice sword can be attacked and broken (AC 15; hp 30; vulnerability to fire and bludgeoning damage; immunity to cold, poison, necrotic, and psychic damage). Breaking a sword deals no damage to the Yeti. A broken sword deals half as much damage (included in the attack).

A broken sword can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 15; hp 15; vulnerability to fire and bludgeoning damage; immunity to cold, poison, necrotic, and psychic damage). Destroying a sword deals no damage to the Yeti.

trait.name: Frigid Swings
entries: All cold damage dealt by the Yeti ignores cold resistance but not cold immunity.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Yeti makes one bite attack and two more weapon attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 1d12 + 8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) slashing damage.

action.name: Ice Sword (Requires Sword)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 15 ft. (or 10 ft. when broken), one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage or 15 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage when the sword is broken.

action.name: Throw Sword (Requires Sword)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage or 15 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage when the sword is broken. The sword is destroyed on a hit or miss.

action.name: Frigid Blast {@recharge 5}
entries: The Yeti exhales frigid air in a 60-foot line that is 5 feet wide followed by another blast of frigid air in a 30-foot cone (centered on the line). Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw, taking 58 ({@damage 13d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Uppercut (3/Long Rest)
entries: The Yeti makes one claw attack against a creature. If the attack hits, the creature takes an extra 36 ({@damage 8d8}) slashing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is launched 20 feet into the air before it falls {@condition prone} in a space 10 feet away from the Yeti, taking an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage from the fall.

reaction.name: Shield
entries: If the Yeti has at least one ice sword, it can shield itself with it. When the Yeti is hit with an attack, it can force attacker to target one of its swords in place of itself.

legendaryHeader: The Yeti can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The Yeti regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Yeti makes one attack with its claw or ice sword.

legendary.name: Jump
entries: The Yeti jumps up to 30 feet away without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Ground Smash (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Yeti slams its paws into the ground, creating difficult terrain in a 30-foot line that is 20 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 33 ({@damage 6d10}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. On a failed or successful save, the target falls {@condition prone}. Unattended objects and structures take 60 damage from this attack, potentially causing them to collapse.
{@i From the howling, churning blizzard, a single silhouette emerges. Tall and bulky, a long, blue blade extends from its forearm, glowing amidst the storm.}

{@b King of the North.} Unlike true yetis, the Yeti is a mere animal, though that doesn’t make it any less deadly. This ape-like ursine traverses the frozen wastes with ease, leaping from glacier to glacier and braving the roar of the North. From the Remorhaz to the mammoth, every arctic creature knows to avoid the king of the north. Even white dragons know to fear the might of a king.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: Thousand Teeth can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Thousand Teeth fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: Thousand Teeth regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point.

trait.name: Water Lurker
entries: Thousand Teeth has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks while submerged in water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Thousand Teeth makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}38 ({@damage 2d20 + 6}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}) and {@condition restrained}, and Thousand Teeth can't bite another target. Thousand Teeth does not need to roll additional attack rolls with its bite against creatures it has {@condition grappled}, and the attack automatically hits.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Death Roll
entries: {@atk mw} one target it has {@condition grappled}. {@h}41 ({@damage 6d12 + 6}) piercing damage. If Thousand Teeth and the target are both underwater, this attack is considered a critical hit.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Thousand Teeth makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Lunge
entries: Thousand Teeth moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Bite (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Thousand Teeth makes a bite attack.

Thousand Teeth is an ancient crocodilian nightmare that has served as the apex predator in the swamps near Saltmarsh for as long as anyone can remember. This monster recently fought a number of lizardfolk and lost one of its teeth. Angered and hungry, it sulks in its lair, lost in primal dreams of rending and tearing. It is found in the deep marshes in Danger at Dunwater.

trait.name: Reactive Heads
entries: The three-headed cobra gets two extra reactions that can be used only for opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Three-headed
entries: The cobra has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the three-headed cobra sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The three-headed cobra makes three bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
