entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. Additionally, the bitten creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} and take {@damage 1d6} Constitution damage. A {@condition poisoned} creature repeats the saving throw every four hours, taking another {@damage 1d6} Constitution damage for each failure, until it has made two consecutive successful saves or survived for 24 hours. The creature dies if its Constitution score reaches 0. If the creature survives, the effect ends and the creature can heal normally. Lost Constitution can be regained with a lesser restoration spell or comparable magic.

{@i This monstrous serpent's body is as thick as a man's torso and covered in ink-black scales. Its trunk branches out to support three hissing heads atop flaring cobra hoods. For all its size, it slithers across the ground almost silently.}
Often employed as guardians, the native intelligence of these creatures makes them capable of learning commands.

entries.name: Color Variations
entries: The three-headed cobra is most common throughout warm climates, though not unknown on the open plains and in some jungles. While most retain the black coloration found in jungles and hills, other varieties exist. The desert variety often has a pale bone color and skull-like hood pattern; the plains varieties tend toward green or khaki coloration.

entries.name: Golden Guardians
entries: The three-headed cobra is a watchful creature associated with guarding shrines and sometimes with rulership over a particular abandoned city or necropolis. Some believe they are protectors of ancient holy relics, sacred scrolls, or divine sparks. Because one of its heads is always awake and alert, it is also favored to guard treasure vaults and counting houses, where large sums of coins are stored. In these cases, the three-headed cobra's scales take on a golden or silvery coloration.

entries.name: Servants of the Queen
entries: The three-headed cobra carries a strong association with the Queen of Serpents, who, according to legend, never strays far from their protection (honor guards of at least two and as many as a dozen are common near the Queen). They are thought to be her close companions, and many believe the three-headed cobras serve not only as her bodyguards but also as her consorts.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The tidehunter can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Net Maker
entries: With 1 minute of work, the tidehunter can create a net out of seaweed, rope, or similar material. The tidehunter typically carries 2 net.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage.
entries: The tidehunter has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tidehunter makes three attacks, only one of which can be with its net. It can use Reel in place of two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 5) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). The tidehunter has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target}

action.name: Net
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +8} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}A Large or smaller creature hit by the net is {@condition restrained} until it is freed. The net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger.  A creature can use its action to make a {@dc 16} Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 15 slashing damage to the net (AC 13) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

action.name: Reel
entries: The tidehunter pulls one creature {@condition restrained} by its net up to 20 feet straight toward it. If the target is within 10 feet of the tidehunter at the end of this pull, the tidehunter can make one claw attack against it as a bonus action.

reaction.name: Entangle Weapon
entries: When the tidehunter is targeted by a melee weapon attack, the attacker must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or miss the attack as the tidehunter uses its net to interfere with the weapon. The tidehunter must have an empty net to use this reaction.

Emerging from the surf, this massive crab-like beast has a hard, blue shell covered in barnacles. It holds a net of seaweed between its barbed claws, and a look of intelligence gleams in its elliptical, crimson eyes.

entries.name: Lurkers in the Shallows
entries: The tidehunter is an ambush hunter, using its coloration to surprise prey that venture into the shallows. Tidehunters are normally found along coasts with plentiful beaches and underwater vegetation, but some can be found in large lakes and river systems close to the open ocean. Most tidehunters are more than 20 feet across and are powerful enough to overcome a {@creature hunter shark} or small whale with ease. They have few natural predators, their intelligence and guile making them challenging prey.

entries.name: Net Weavers
entries: Tidehunters can weave nets out of kelp, seaweed, and other fibrous plant material with ease, constructing nets in a matter of minutes with the weirdly hooked barbs on their claws. Their nets are strong and can be thrown with great accuracy over a large distance. Indeed, even those on dry land are not immune to the tidehunter's attacks, and more than one human has been hauled into the surging tide from the apparent safety of the beach.

entries.name: Fishing Buddies
entries: While fisherfolk and tidehunters are normally at odds, a tidehunter will sometimes enter into an unspoken agreement with a group of fisherfolk, sharing the spoils of the sea while keeping out of each other's way.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The timingila deals double damage to objects, structures, and vehicles.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The timingila can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The timingila makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail slap.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}40 ({@damage 3d20 + 9}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the timingila. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the timingila, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the timingila's turns.

If the timingila takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the timingila must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the timingila. If the timingila dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail Slap
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +15} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 6d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 30 feet away from the timingila and knocked {@condition prone}. If the target fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it is also {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Breach
entries: The timingila swims up to its swimming speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks}. If it breaches the water's surface, it crashes back down, creating a wave in a 30-foot-wide, 120-foot-long line that is 30 feet tall. Any Gargantuan or smaller creatures, objects, and vehicles in the line are carried up to 100 feet away from the timingila and have a {@chance 50} chance of capsizing.

action.name: Resonating Roar {@recharge 5}
entries: The timingila roars in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 45 ({@damage 10d8}) thunder damage and is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition deafened}. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a vehicle is in the area, the roar travels into the vehicle and resonates inside it. Each creature inside the vehicle, even if the creature is outside the roar's area, must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or take half the damage from the roar.
This massive shark-eel surges out of the water, opening titanic jaws large enough to bite a ship in half.

entries.name: Bribable
entries: Wise captains traveling through timingila hunting grounds often carry tithes and offerings in hopes of placating the creatures.

entries.name: Lesser Leviathan
entries: The timingila is one of the largest creatures in the seas, reaching lengths of up to 300 feet long. Some scholarly tomes suggest a connection between the timingila and rarer {@creature leviathan|mtf|leviathans} but no definitive proof has yet been found.

entries.name: Master of the Seas
entries: The timingila is an apex predator of the oceans. It hunts whales primarily but eats anything it can catch. The timingila is fiercely territorial and considers all of the ocean its personal domain.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If it dies, the torternal returns to life in {@dice 1d6} days and regains all its hit points. Only a {@spell wish} spell can prevent this trait from functioning.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

trait.name: Miser's Fury
entries: The treasure tegu knows the scent of every coin, gem and item of value in its hoard. The tegu has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception} and {@skill Survival}) checks to find and track its hoard. In addition, it has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if the creature is in possession of any portion of its hoard.

trait.name: Treasure Sense
entries: A treasure tegu can pinpoint, by scent, the location of precious metals and minerals, such as coins and gems, within 60 feet of it. In addition, it can differentiate between various types of metals and minerals and can determine if the metal or mineral is magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The treasure tegu makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Midas Breath {@recharge 6}
entries: The treasure tegu spits molten gold in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 62 ({@damage 8d10}) fire damage and molten gold clings to it. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and the gold doesn't cling to it. A creature with gold clinging to it has its speed halved, has disadvantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws, and takes 6 (1d10) fire damage at the start of each of its turns until it takes an action to scrape off the gold.
The gold produced by the treasure tegu's Midas Breath can be collected once it has cooled, providing roughly 50 gp worth of gold dust and scraps each time it spits molten gold.
{@i A plump, wingless reptile with golden scales and glowing amber eyes lounges on a pile of treasure. When it opens its crooked maw, molten gold drips from its jaws.}

{@b Miser Lizard.} Treasure tegus are perhaps the most avaricious and lazy of all reptiles, spending their days lying on huge mounds of copper, silver, and gold pieces, rarely—if ever—venturing out of their lairs. Treasure tegus feed irregularly, gorging themselves on metals, minerals, and the occasional dwarf or goat when hunger finally gets the better of them. Treasure tegus are almost as vain as they are greedy and meticulously clean their scales to a polished gleam that matches their golden treasure. Treasure tegus are known to hunt and devour dragons for their hoards, slowly incorporating them into their own treasure troves.

{@b Thieves Beware.} Strangely, treasure tegus are docile creatures by nature and are openly tolerant of non-hostile creatures exploring their domains. However, treasure tegus are prone to terrible wrath when even the smallest portion of their treasure is taken. At such times, a treasure tegu leaves its lair to relentlessly pursue the thief, not resting until its treasure is reclaimed and the offending party is slain and eaten. A treasure tegu never gives up any part of its hoard unless threatened with certain death.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The two-headed eagle doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Two-headed
entries: The eagle has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the two-headed eagle sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The two-headed eagle makes two bite attacks and one talons attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the two-headed eagle can't use its talons on another target.

{@i With two sets of sharp eyes and razor-sharp beaks, the two-headed eagle spots its prey and snatches it up with frightening speed. Drawn to shiny objects, the eagle swoops down, snatching a mounted knight from its horse.}

{@b Hunters of the Unseen.} Enormous birds of prey, twoheaded eagles soar the skies of many parts of the world, using their extraordinarily keen vision to hunt down prey and threats to their nests alike. Their ability to see invisible creatures has led to many ill-fated attempts to raid their nests; the same ability that makes them so sought after as potential guardians also makes their nests nigh impossible to approach undetected.

{@b Dangerous Favorites.} Considered to be wise birds, they are nonetheless attracted to shiny objects, much to the dismay of the occasional, armored noble. This tendency, coupled with their disdain for herds of livestock as prey, has played a large role in their continued favor among villagers and country folk in many lands. While two-headed eagles do feed on deer, elk, and other game favored by hunters, their preferred prey consists of giant snakes, wild and dire boar, and large river fish.

{@b Symbol of the Watchful.} Known for their ability to see the invisible, two-headed eagles appear frequently on coats of arms, symbolizing watchfulness, a dedication to truth, or a wariness for deception or assassins.

trait.name: Frenzy (1/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the ubiystov can trigger a berserker's frenzy that lasts for 1 minute. While in a frenzy, the ubiystov gains resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and has advantage on attack rolls. Attack rolls made against the ubiystov have advantage.

trait.name: Rabid Courage
entries: The ubiystov has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Corpse Eater
entries: When the ubiytsov hits an undead creature with a bite attack, it regains a number of hit points equal to the damage dealt.

trait.name: Tightening Bite
entries: Any creature that begins its turn {@condition grappled} by the ubiytsov takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The ubiytsov has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ubiytsov makes one bite attack and one claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage plus 6 ({@damage 1d10}) slashing damage if the target is undead. On a hit, the target is {@condition grappled} ({@dc 14}) as the ubiystov clings to its throat. While {@condition grappled}, the target can't breathe and begins suffocating at the beginning of its next turn.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d4 + 4}) slashing damage.

reaction.name: Hatred for Undeath
entries: If the ubiytsov is hit by an undead creature, it can immediately make a claw attack against the attacker.

Commonly referred to as Church Grims, ubiystovs are large wolverines that commonly inhabit graveyards due to their habit of scavenging on the dead. Ravenous and ferocious, ubiystovs in the wild are known to bring down creatures significantly larger than them, such as large bears, hill giants, mammoths, giant elk, and even Remorhaz. There is even a confirmed report of a particularly violent individual bringing down a white dragon, though this is considered a unique and extremely unlikely outcome. To sate their gluttonous nature, however, ubiystovs often lair in humanoid cemeteries, digging up corpses in the dead of night to eat bones and all. These animals would be considered dangerous pests if it weren’t for their particular and violent hatred for the undead. When the rotting walk once again, a ubiystov will fly into a terrific, bloodthirsty rage until the corpse has been shredded and devoured. Many undeath-opposers utilize ubiystovs to counter undead threats for this reason.

Surprisingly, the closest-living relative to the ubiystov isn’t the wolverine, but the savager. Larger, stronger, and bulkier, savagers are clearly the dominant animal when the two encounter one another, though savagers are known to actively avoid ubiystovs for their significantly more rabid disposition.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ursa polaris' innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 17}, +9 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The ursa polaris has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The ursa polaris can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The ursa polaris has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Rime
entries: An area covered in rime is difficult terrain. Additionally, any creature that ends its turn while touching a frost covered area takes 4 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage and is {@condition grappled} by the frost (escape {@dc 16}).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ursa polaris can make three attacks; one with its bite and two with its claws. Alternatively, it can make two attacks with its frigid spear.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Frigid Spear
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 90/120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 6}) piercing damage. Any creature within 10 feet of the target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage as the spear shatters on impact. The affected area is then covered in rime for 1 minute.

action.name: Icewind Gale {@recharge 5}
entries: The ursa polaris exhales an icy blast of freezing wind in a 60-foot cone. The area is covered in rime for 1 minute and each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 28 ({@damage 8d6}) cold damage on a failed save. Additionally, the creature magically begins to freeze and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified} until freed by the greater restoration spell or other magic. It can't be thawed and is immune to all damage and conditions until freed. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition petrified}.

{@italic Thick, white fur coats this hulking ursine, and massive crystalline shards of ice protrude from its shoulders. When it lets out a mighty roar, frigid breath dances between the jagged sprouts of ice that form its teeth.}

A fearsome sight, the ursa polaris dwarfs even the largest of polar bears. Some believe that they are polar bears blessed or cursed by gods of cold, winter, and the north. Followers of such gods often leave a caribou carcass, whale blubber, or seal meat as an offering to the ursa polaris.

{@bold Creatures of Ice.}The ursa polaris thrives in freezing arctic conditions and is capable of surviving off of ice alone, should other food sources become scarce. They dislike warmth; an ursa polaris will avoid warm waters and curl into its ice cavern when summer comes.

{@bold Fiercely Territorial. }The ursa polaris is a solitary creature, carving a vast swath of territory for itself and going out of its way to kill trespassers. Somewhere within its territory, a female ursa polaris will carve out an ice cavern to rear young; this cavern may be within glacial ice, an iceberg, or simply a frosty stone cavern.
{@bold Icy Breath. }The ursa polaris can exhale a fragment of frigid arctic winds, disabling prey and cocooning them in rime for an easy kill.

trait.name: Brutal Wings
entries: The valstrax deals one extra die of its damage when the valstrax hits with its wing attack (included in the attack).

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The valstrax doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the valstrax is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the valstrax instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The valstrax makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its wing. Alternatively, it attacks three times with its plasmatic hurl.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Wing
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) slashing damage plus an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) force damage.

action.name: Plasmatic Hurl
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 60/100 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) force damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Ignition {@recharge 6}
entries: The valstrax primes its wings, sending a scorching blast of flame sweeping in every direction. Each creature within 15 feet of the valstrax must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) force damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one. The valstrax can then fly up to 400 feet in any direction. Each creature with 10 feet of the valstrax during this movement must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 11 ({@damage 2d10}) thunder damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

bonus.name: Jet Propulsion
entries: While the valstrax is flying, it uses the dash action.
{@i With a thunderous blast, a scaly, bird-like creature weaves through the sky with unmatched speed and skill. A trail of flaming red energy extends behind it.}

{@b Red Comet.} The valstrax is a bird-like reptile with large, wing-like appendages extending from its shoulder blades.  Quick and ruthless, the valstrax dominates the skies, darting and weaving around prey while slashing it to bits. A valstrax’s seemingly supernatural speed is the result of the creature’s specialized anatomy. On the ends of both of the beast’s “wings” are three openings that expel plasma produced via a special organ in its chest.  Known as the atriox, the organ rapidly sucks in air before releasing it through the wings as a form of exhaust. This method of propulsion allows the valstrax to soar at outrageous speeds, making it the fastest flying beast known to scholars. While flying at high speeds, the valstrax soars at such high altitudes that only its crimson exhaust can be seen. This trail of crimson fire has earned it the name “Red Comet.”

{@b Aerial Fighter.} The valstrax rarely fights on the ground. It strikes from above with speed and power, ripping prey to shreds in mere moments. The valstrax is capable of flipping its wings in two different directions: backwards, which allows it to fly at high speeds, and forwards; attacking foes from a distance by expelling plasma as a devastating projectile.

{@b Noble Predator.} While grounded, valstrax are normally quite docile, regularly tolerating the presence of other nonaggressive creatures. Valstrax have even been known to defend smaller and weaker creatures from larger threats. This protective and tolerant behavior has led to many crests and flags bearing the aspect of a valstrax.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lynx's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution. It can cast the following spell, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Smoky Constitution
entries: The vapor lynx spends its time in both gaseous and solid form. Its unique constitution makes it immune to all fog- or gas-related spells and attacks, including its own. A vapor lynx sees clearly through light or heavy obscurement caused by fog, mist, or spells such as {@spell fog cloud}.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the vapor lynx moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the vapor lynx can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vapor lynx makes one bite attack and two claw attacks. While in vapor form, the vapor lynx can only make one attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Poison Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The vapor lynx exhales a cloud of poisonous fog in 40-foot radius, which heavily obscures a spherical area around the lynx. Any breathing creature that ends its turn in the fog must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for {@dice 1d4 + 1} rounds. The fog lasts until the end of the vapor lynx's next turn.

bonus.name: Vapor Form
entries: The vapor lynx magically transforms into a cloud of gray mist, dropping everything it is currently carrying. While in this form, the vapor lynx’s only method of movement is a flying speed of 80 feet and it does not provoke opportunity attacks. The vapor lynx can enter and occupy the space of another creature and has resistance to nonmagical damage. The vapor lynx also has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution checks and saving throws. While in vapor form, the vapor lynx can pass through small holes, narrow openings, and even mere cracks, though it treats liquids as though they were solid surfaces. The vapor lynx can't fall and remains hovering in the air even when {@condition stunned} or otherwise {@condition incapacitated}. While in this form, the vapor lynx can’t carry objects, but it can move and manipulate anything weighing less than its Strength modifier x 10.

reaction.name: Misty Shift
entries: When the vapor lynx takes damage, it can quickly shift into vapor form, potentially gaining resistance against the incoming damage. The vapor lynx returns to its normal form at the end of the current turn.

{@i These great cats pad noiselessly, while tendrils of smoke drift off their sleek gray coats, leaving misty whorls in their wake. Their eyes shift from dull, pallid orbs to pitch black slits. Their lips curl up into a fang-revealing smile as their bodies fades into fog.}

entries.name: Split the Herd
entries: Vapor lynxes are capricious hunters. Devious, manipulative, and mischievous, they toy with their prey before killing it. They rarely enjoy a stand-up fight, instead coalescing in and out of the fog to harass victims. Using their ability to solidify and poison the fog around them, they cut large groups into smaller, more manageable morsels.

entries.name: Dreary Marshlands
entries: Their tactics have earned vapor lynxes a nasty reputation and the occasional bounty on their heads. Additionally, their magical nature makes them valuable to practitioners of the magical arts, and their beautiful, thick coats tempt many a furrier into hunts they may not be prepared for. For these reasons, vapor lynxes avoid civilization, fearing organized reprisal. Instead they haunt marshes and swamps, where the natural fog makes hunting easier. If an intelligent humanoid passes their way, they are happy for a change in their diet.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Violothéos has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Primal Strikes
entries: Violothéos' attacks are considered magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: Violothéos deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Trample
entries: When Violothéos enters a creature's space for the first time on a turn, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Violothéos can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Atomic Absorption
entries: Whenever Violothéos is subjected to radiant damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the damage dealt. Additionally, Violothéos' breath weapon immediately recharges.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Violothéos fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Atomic Force
entries: Violothéos is an overwhelming force of atomic annihilation. Each creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of Violothéos is subjected to the sickening radiance spell (save {@dc 21}). Additionally, the growth of plants and other flora is provoked into hyperactivity due to the radiation, causing areas affected by Violothéos' destruction to be  entirely overtaken by various flora in {@damage 1d4 x 10} days.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Violothéos makes four attacks: one with its bite, two with its claws, and one with its tail. It can't make a tail attack against the same target it hits with a bite attack. It can make a Swallow attack in place of a bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}33 ({@damage 5d12 + 10}) piercing damage and an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and Violothéos can't bite another target.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 4d6 + 10}) slashing damage and an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage and an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Swallow
entries: Violothéos makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, that creature takes the bite's damage and is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside of Violothéos , and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage at the start of each of Violothéos' turns.

If Violothéos takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of it. If Violothéos dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: Violothéos uses one of the following breath weapons.

{@bold Atomic Breath.} Violothéos exhales atomic energy in a line that is 90 feet long and 10 feet wide. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

{@bold Nuclear Burst.} Violothéos becomes super-heated with atomic energy, expelling a devastating nuclear blast outwards in a 40-foot radius blast around it. Each creature caught in the blast must succeed on a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw or take 22 (6d10) radiant and thunder damage, be pushed up to 30 feet away from Violothéos, and be knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half the radiant and thunder damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}. A creature is {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour as a result of the blast. While {@condition poisoned} this way, the target's movement speed is halved and it has disadvantage on Strength checks or saving throws. Additionally, the creature only deals half damage with a melee weapon attack or an unarmed strike. The creature can repeat the initial Constitution save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Shockwave
entries: Violothéos rears up and comes crashing down to earth. All creatures and structures on the ground within 100 feet of Violothéos (other than itself) are affected as they would be by the {@spell earthquake} spell (save {@dc 21}).

legendary.name: Rush
entries: Violothéos moves up to its speed.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Violothéos makes a tail or claw attack.

legendary.name: Roar (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Each creature that is within 120 feet of Violothéos and can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Violothéos' Roar for the next 24 hours.

{@italic Stirring from its century-long slumber, a creature of titanic proportions surfaces from deep within the ocean. Lesser beings flee in its wake, careful not to be crushed underfoot by the massive beast as it makes landfall. Its sheer presence ionizes the surrounding environment, causing strange mutations in organisms after prolonged exposure. The titan lets out a grumbling roar that echoes for miles. Violothéos has awakened.}

{@bold Radioactive Titan.} Closely related to a smaller genus of innately radioactive spinosaurids, Violothéos has grown to a massive size through unknown means. Some claim that the beast is a close relative of the tarrasque, but given its close ties to a separate, smaller species, it may be safe to assume that this is not the case. It is widely believed that the beast was mutated by overexposure to arcane radiation, which it exerts a peculiar mastery over. Violothéos’ signature weapon is its “atomic breath,” nuclear energy that it generates inside of its body, harnessing electromagnetic force to concentrate it into a laser-like high velocity projectile. The energy is released in the form of a pink radioactive beam, which is capable of melting and vaporizing anything it comes into contact with. Through a similar method, Violothéos can exhale a wave of lethal radiation, irradiating anything it passes through. It is capable of both bipedal and quadrupedal locomotion, although it primarily moves quadrupedally whilst moving terrestrially. Two tusks at the tip of its jaw allow it to grasp and pierce more effectively, along with its peculiar ability to unhinge its jaw similar to a snake. The lizard is naturally immune to extreme heat, cold, radiation, and most forms of conventional weaponry, making it a true force of ultimate calamity.

{@bold Indifferent Guardian.} While Violothéos clearly possesses the ability to lay waste to most life on the continents, it instead chooses to remain sealed away in the darkest crevasses of the sea, slumbering in wait for a global threat to arise. When the planet is faced with global annihilation, the Violothéos will awaken, using its atomic might to topple any foe. When active, Violothéos will remain indifferent to and oftentimes completely ignore all smaller life, regarding them as a warrior would a mere ant. This can prove to be destructive at times, causing Violothéos to lay waste to villages and cities along its journey.

{@bold Misunderstood Defender.} Oftentimes, a powerful city or hold will use magic to retaliate against Violothéos. While the massive reptile is naturally resistant to the arcane, it is not immune. If sufficiently damaged, Violothéos will defend itself, targeting the attackers and casting them into oblivion with its atomic fury. This usually leads to further destruction, which causes many to resent Violothéos, assuming it to be a malevolent force. This could not be further from the truth, and thus Violothéos lives a very conflicted life, attacked by the very creatures it attempts to defend.

{@b (DISCLAIMER: THIS CREATURE'S CHALLENGE RATING IS NOT ACCURATE. SEVERAL TEMPLATES HAVE BEEN APPLIED TO THE BASE CREATURE (Young Spinosaurus) ALONG WITH A FEW FLUFF ABILITIES, MAKING THIS CREATURE ROUGHLY CR 11 AFTER ALL TEMPLATES HAVE BEEN APPLIED. IN REALITY, THIS CREATURE IS ABOUT CR 24. USE CAUTIOUSLY WHEN BALANCING FOR AN ENCOUNTER.)}

trait.name: Ever-Sharp Horns
entries: The ychen bannog deals triple damage dice when it scores a critical hit with a gore attack. In addition, its gore attacks are magical and score a critical hit on a roll of 18-20.

trait.name: Overrun
entries: When the ychen bannog takes the {@action Dash} action, it can move through the space of a Large or smaller creature, treating the creature's space as difficult terrain. As it moves through the creature's space, the ychen bannog can make a stomp attack as a bonus action.

trait.name: Peaceful Creature
entries: The ychen bannog abhors combat and flees from it if possible. If unable to flee, the ychen bannog can attack a foe or obstacle to clear a path to safety. As an action, a driver or handler mounted on the ychen bannog or adjacent to it can make a {@dc 16} Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the ychen bannog moves and attacks as directed by the driver. On a failure, the beast flees. The driver or handler must have proficiency in Animal Handling to attempt this check.

trait.name: Beast of Burden
entries: The ychen bannog can haul up to 500,000 tons of weight.

trait.name: Sturdy
entries: When the ychen bannog fails a Constitution saving throw that deals damage, it takes only half damage. On a success, it takes no damage.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The ychen bannog deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the ychen bannog moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the ychen bannog can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ychen bannog makes one gore attack and one stomp attack.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d12 + 10}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 20 feet away from the ychen bannog.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Destroying Bellow {@recharge 5}
entries: The ychen bannog delivers a fearsome bellow that can be heard up to ten miles away. Structures and unattended objects in a 60-foot cone take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) thunder damage. Creatures in the cone take 27 ({@damage 5d10}) thunder damage and are {@condition deafened} for 1 hour, or take half damage and aren't {@condition deafened} with a successful {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw.

{@i Ychen bannogs are massive, ox-like beasts with thick, wooly coats and great horns like the gods' battering rams. They stand over 40 feet tall at the shoulder and weigh hundreds of tons. Despite their awe-inspiring size, these towering creatures are peaceful wanderers in the wilderness, where their calls echo for miles.}

entries.name: Strongest Beasts in the World
entries: Legends are built on their sturdy backs. Capable of pulling 670 tons (or carrying 134 tons on their backs), ychen bannogs are the strongest beasts of burden in the known world. Tamed ychen bannogs can haul entire communities, or even small castles, and a clever dwarf with a ychen bannog at her disposal can carve out enormous riverbeds, haul enormous stones, or reshape entire valleys with ease.

entries.name: Ychen Warships
entries: Giants have a particular affinity with the ychen bannogs. In times of war, giants sometimes build complex siege platforms atop these beasts, making effective transport for small armies of giants. Thankfully, ychen bannogs are rare enough that even seeing one in an army is a tale to be told for generations.

entries.name: Louder Than Thunder
entries: When riled, a ychen bannog can bellow loudly enough to shatter stones and knock down walls.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The zorbo has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Natural Armor
entries: The zorbo magically absorbs the natural strength of its surroundings, adjusting its Armor Class based on the material it is standing or climbing on: AC 15 for wood or bone, AC 17 for earth or stone, or AC 19 for metal. If the zorbo isn't in contact with any of these substances, its AC is 10.

action.name: Destructive Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) slashing damage, and if the target is a creature wearing armor, carrying a shield, or in possession of a magic item that improves its AC, it must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, one such item worn or carried by the creature (the target's choice) magically deteriorates, taking a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers, and the zorbo gains a +1 bonus to AC until the start of its next turn. Armor reduced to an AC of 10 or a shield or magic item that drops to a 0 AC increase is destroyed.

A zorbo (pronounced ZOR-boh) is a ferocious omnivore similar in size and appearance to a koala. Living in trees and caves, it has long claws, a dour disposition, and a fondness for humanoid flesh. A zorbo alters its natural armor to match its surroundings, and it can weaken and destroy armor, shields, and protective magic items with its sharp claws.

monster.name: Zouyu
languages: understands all languages but can't speak; telepathy 120 ft.

trait.name: Distance Runner
entries: The zouyu is capable of incredibly fast long-distance travel. When traveling at a fast pace, the zouyu can run 310 miles per day.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The zouyu has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the zouyu moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the zouyu can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Indomitable Fortune (5/Day)
entries: If the zouyu fails a saving throw or ability check, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zouyu uses Alter Luck. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Alter Luck
entries: The zouyu flicks its vibrant, multi-stranded tail and alters the luck of one creature it can see within 30 feet of it, choosing one of the following luck options. The zouyu can't target itself with Alter Luck.

items.name: Bestow Luck.
items.entry: The target has advantage on the next ability check, attack roll, or saving throw (zouyu's choice) it makes before the end of its next turn.

items.name: Steal Luck
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on the next ability check, attack roll, or saving throw (zouyu's choice) it makes before the end of its next turn. If the target fails the saving throw, the zouyu has advantage on one attack roll or saving throw it makes before the start of its next turn.

reaction.name: Unleash Possibility {@recharge 5}
entries: The zouyu warps the fabric of chance and fortune, creating a sea of possibility. If a creature within 30 feet of the zouyo other than itself makes an ability check, saving throw, or attack roll, the zouyu can use a reaction to make the creature succeed or fail regardless of the roll. An attack roll changed in this way is treated as a critical hit if the zouyu allows it to succeed or a critical failure if the zouyu allows it to miss.
This elephant-sized feline has sleek fur, four upwardturned fangs in its mouth, and a long tail ending in multiple strands like a pheasant.

entries.name: Familial Bonds
entries: Zouyu live as mated pairs with large territories. The great felines are gentle and social creatures, often overlapping their territories for mutual protection.

entries.name: Good Luck
entries: For many, the zouyu are symbols of good luck and fortune. The tail feather of a zouyu, freely given, can be rendered into a liquid, which produces a luck potion. The potion brings minor good fortune, such as finding a fruit tree when hungry or shelter when it rains, to the drinker for a day. If a tail feather is taken without the zouyu's knowledge, the potion created by the feather bestows bad luck on the drinker for a day. Such bad luck manifests as the drinker tripping over a too-perfectly-placed rock or a lightning strike felling a tree onto the drinker's path.
